description: No cover charge, drinks were decently priced. Parking is a bitch in the financial district so good luck with that. They have a $20 credit card minimum to buy drinks. Bullshit, get out of the dark ages. The DJ was trying to play his ghetto ass gangsta rap to please his boys from the hood but seriously, nobody was even dancing when he played those ignorant ass songs. So a little advice to the bar, get a DJ who plays music people actually want to dance to so it will prompt them to buy more drinks at the bar which therefore increases your revenue by the end of the night. Funny how simple economics work. Overall it's a decent place to party. I like to switch it up from the usual parlor, grand and sloane. This is a good alternative with a nice vibe. Just get the DJ in check and get your credit card debacle sorted out and we got a poppin place.
author: Jeromy G.

description:
Crowd is late 20s-early 30s young professionals and the drinks are ok.

Thursday nights are old school hip hop night and it can get pretty crackin'!
author: Yonder B.

description: I've only been here for a few nights out, so I'm not sure of the restaurant.  At night, they charge a small cover and have a live DJ in a very confined, small dance space.  The bartenders are very prompt - never had trouble getting a drink.  Overall, this bar is part of my SoMA "bar crawl" to Local Edition, Novela, John Colins, etc.
author: Andrew H.

description: Music is okay. Bar is okay. They're helpful and they'll notice you but the crowd and the atmosphere of the bar is whack. No one wants to talk to you... I prefer bamboo hut on broadway though. More diverse, they got the best playlist (new rnb n hiphop and 90s music), and a way better crowd. Everyone's friendly af!
author: Kayla D.

description:
One of my favorite places to go for Happy Hour since it reminds me of bars in Hawaii.  I love the decor and the layout.  It's casual without being dive-y.  The crowd is young and a good mix of yuppy and hipster. The basil gimlets are great and refreshing and the staff is super nice and attentive.  Extra points for the little snacks of pretzels and goldfish they give out.   " I love goldfishes cuz they're so delicious, gone goldfishing, gone goldfishing... "  

Okay I'll stop now.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Went here two times already, and I loved every visit.

1. Free, no cover.

2.Not insanely packed on weekend nights. You have room to dance and have space.

3.Love the hip hop nights. I'm tired of house and trance, it's annoying.

4.The place is nicely layed out, with a bar and a dance floor.
author: Daisy M.

description:
ANECDOTAL INTRO TO REVIEW:

believe it or not, i actually used the yelp-o 'bookmark' function for this place after reading some great reviews, and last night when i went, i realized i had been here a few times before when i first moved to sf. after all, when a good friend has a gigantor crush on a bartender at a certain bar, you often frequent that place even though it is kinda out of your way and you deal with the weirdness that occurs when your friend is not getting the response she wants and becomes neurotic about shit... and when this happens you tend to drink maybe more than you would normally to keep yourself and your friend amused and feeling 'friendly' while she desperately tries to work her magic, thereby forgetting the damn name of the bar you are at and later bookmarking it like a retard thinking 'that place sounds great!'  

SELF-INDULGENT FOLLOW UP TO ANECDOTAL INTRO:

so, i began to run into my friend's hot bartender guy all over the damn place (rainbow, coffee shops, doing laundry, other bars, etc.) and i even created some weirdo pet name for him like 'pelicanhead' or 'gooseruffles' or something equally as dumb which i would always refer to him as. it was cute.  i thought he was cute.  i think he thought i was cute. my friend was pissed. i had a boyf at the time, didn't want ANY drama and so i backed the hell off.  

USEFUL PORTION OF REVIEW:

the point is that this bar has well mixed drinks, exposed brick walls, cool looking art, a relaxing atmosphere, hot bartenders (duh), plenty of seats, decent djs, room to dance, a large and crazy eyed doorman who has a wicked awesome memory and will call you out by name when you get too loud outside, no cover charge on friday nights, and i have never had a bad time here...  good stuff.
author: Karen K.

description: We wanted to dance after having drinks elsewhere. Dropped $5 cover at the door. The dance floor was small but it had a cozy feel. It kind of had that house party vibe. The music on tap was good. We danced a bit then headed to the next venue when it got too crowded.
author: Jo H.

description: Basil gimlets were good,  though I wouldn't want to pay full price for them so definitely go during happy hour. Nice ambiance.
author: Stephen F.

description: Pretty chill cute little spot. Decor is awesome and love the bar staff, they are so awesome and pretty knowledgeable about mixology in general.  Went for the HayaHon pop up which is bomb! Happy hour, little fresh fish, a yummy drink and awesome music? Definitely a great way to start a Friday night off!
author: N. M.

description: I've been to John Collins a couple of times now, its a great bar to go to after work with coworkers. Its a pretty large area, but get there early if you want seating. They also have a lounge area upstairs where they sell sushi. My favorite drink there is their Moscow Mules, they make them super good. =)
author: Stephanie T.

description:
There are so many eye-pleasing attractions to be found here: the crowd always seems to be easy on the eyes and not too hip, the petite brunette bartender is gorgeous, the paintings are always evocative, they play killer surf videos on the wall (I can watch those all day!), and the petite brunette bartender is gorgeous (oops, did I mention that already?).

Combine all that with attentive service and decent music selections (at least when I can hear it) and you can't go too wrong here. 

More like 4.5 stars but I'll bump it up to 5 just cause I'm cool like that and cause the petite brunette bartender is gorgeous! ;^)
author: Art O.

description: No cover charge, quick bar service, but very small dance area. They should expand the dance floor since their bar area takes up a lot of space. The scene can get kind of dull because of this. This place has both equal pros and cons.
author: Briget P.

description:
Two stars for the super rad pit- and bulldog artwork on the walls. I want all of it for my apartment. Too bad it didn't really have an effect on my super mediocre experience here. In fact, it's a certain subset of SOMA bars like this one that make me actually want to hang out in, say, the Marina. I can't believe I just typed that.

Anyway, I mean to say that the vibe at this place (and others like it in the area) is completely weird. You think you're going into a club, what with the velvet rope line and the bouncer and the loud music, but then you get inside and it's just a fancy bar with no dance floor. That makes very little sense to me. Also, the crowd is... hilarious. Overly-suited men, underly-clad women, lots of yelling, you fill in the rest. I'm sure it could be a cool place to hang out on another given night, but my first impression was not a flattering one.
author: Stefanie L.

description:
Of all the 2nd street bars John Collins would be one of my favorites.  

Ski Lodge decor? check  
Bouncers with a sense of humor? check  
Good happy hour?  check  
Better than wasting your time at Harlot?  check

Last night the crowd came in waves so although you'd be packed in for about 30 minutes the next 30 you had plenty of space to move around.  The bartenders are attentive and do well with the usually crowded bar, the only drawback to John Collins is they have one bathrooom, ONE!  Although that seems the norm for the 2nd street bars, we left and used a bathroom around the corner.  It was actually faster.   The place is par in size to the rest of the bars but I like it better, I just do.  The attitude is better, the crowd is better, get the point?  Better!
author: Kristin Marie S.

description: Came here for happy hour on a Friday.. it was really really packed. You can barely move. You need good luck to be able to order drinks at the bar LOL. But it's a cool spot, with DJ playing, large screen TV to lounge, drinks were strong, prices are not bad.
author: Vol T.

description:
HAPPY HOUR! YAY!
There's only one reason why people would cram themsevles into a tiny bar and wait over 15mins for a beer! Only dislike was it being too crowded at the bar area, haha. The rest of the space was nice, open and loved the brick walls.

The bartenders are fast and very nice, but slammed. WOW. perhaps build another bar in the smaller room to kinda relieve the chaos and wait time. Just a thought. 
Loved the DJ, my friends and I were taken down memory lane with the old school hip hop music selection. Perfect.
author: tiffany d.

description: Came here not dressed, but was spontaneous so we went in to check it out. Went in with a few of my friends and got the feel that this place is pretty hipster. They serve their cocktail drinks in mason jars :) There's another worker walking around selling sweets and whatnot too, but I'm not sure if they do that normally, or because it was St. Patrick's Day weekend. The bathrooms were not too dirty for a club, but I do like the posters they put in there. The location is in an alleyway so it could be easily missed. It was $5 for cover that night, and the dance floor is a bit too small. What really gave this place 4 stars is because they played old school hip-hop all night!!!! Some jams I haven't heard since high school or middle school days! Didn't expect much from here, but left pretty happy that I came. Hopefully next time my friends plan to go to a club, it would be this one!
author: Amanda C.

description: Came extra late on a Saturday night, line was about ten minutes. Cover fee was $10 for guys and $5 for girls, already a disappointment right there. The bouncers are pretentious, especially the Asian one with the fedora and cigar. Pretty crowded, overpriced and water-downed drinks. Dance floor was small and crowded and occupied primarily by men. The music that night was strictly hip-hop, the latino and filipino groups loved it, not so much anyone else. Now that I've looked up some of the reviews, all the good reviews focus on their happy hour and the bad reviews basically summarize everything else about the place.
author: Ryan L.

description:
Hopped over here from the House of Shields on night and it was a much better fit for my group of coworkers. You can grab your own (extra salty) pretzels and goldfishes at the end of the bar. I didn't know this until half a second after sitting down my coworker comes over with 2 bowls like he works there!

As you know, drinks can get pretty pricey, but you're there for the atmosphere! There was also a live band on Tuesday. Check it out if you're looking for a place to go in that area. :)
author: Wendy L.

description:
Since I just moved to San Francisco and just started working at a start-up in Downtown, Im always open to new spots for happy hour.    Last week, one of my good friends took me to this spot after a long day.  Well- Monday morning... I came back to work letting all my colleagues know that this is a great spot for happy hour!

As a bartender  in my past life,  I can be pretty picky with my drinks- well, at this spot... drinks are very well- balanced! Go to Jason or Tahaj They helped us that evening.  Not only were the gentlemen attentive, knew how to make drinks, but were very cool!  The great news is being a professional in the city- in downtown, I only know of a couple other places that I really enjoy the ambiance and crowd.  This will be one of frequent drinking holes! Normal working professional crowd (but if you stay too long- around 10ish, it changes), great drinks,  and cool bartenders! AND they have the GIANTS games on the Big Screen! 

You gotta try their Tequila drinks on the menu.  I normally a vodka drinker but there were sooo good. If Jason does a fine job helping you, order Jameson shots for you, him, and company!
author: Christina S.

description: 5-stars because the bar has a great selection of whiskey. The dance floor is a little small, but that may not be a bad thing if you're a 50-60 employee company looking for a place to hold a company party. The venue is convenient to nearby parking structures and there is a seating area.
author: Marfel L.

description:
A friend who lives in SOMA but knows nothing about night spots wanted to meet me recently, so I had to find a place and I selected this one based on positive Yelpings. Needless to say, the bar was set high ...

John Collins did not disappoint. The space was nice and open, with an enclosed 2nd floor in the rear of the building. The bar was a nice dark wood, with those nifty little hooks under the bar for your jacket (I love those things). Also, they projected a movie onto the wall above the front door, which lent a nice art house vibe to the place.


Our bartender was awesome, and even managed to concoct a decent shot that had no vodka or tequila in it. Didn't taste too bad, either. Points to him. This was also during the infamous Happy Hour (which on a Monday was not crowded at all), so the drinks were nice and cheap, too. Yay for cheap booze!

One downside: the bath rooms were a little skeevy. They could use a touch up in that department.
author: Wes T.

description: For what it is, it's a cool place. Draws the after work tech crowd for a beer. Mostly standing room but lots of it. Good place to bring a group - easy to mingle. Wait staff are attentive and helpful. Always had a good time.
author: Omar S.

description: This place is usually consistent with the service . The Bartenders are on their A-game and the music is usually on point . I get the feeling security doesn't really appreciate my presence. It's a drag to be turned down with a hat when the guy in front of me got in with one. I must have a doppelganger in the area that rubbed these guys the wrong way. Besides the security thing , this place is usually a good time.
author: Bryan Y.

description:
John Colins boasted a drink called the Bitter Grandpa -- a whiskey sour with a dash of pale ale -- so I ordered it because I like whiskey sours and pale ales and bitter grandpas. Alas, the bartenders at John Colins have either never attended bartending school or never read a basic cocktail book because they made me a seven and seven (whiskey and sprite) with a dash of pale ale rather than a whiskey sour (whiskey, lemon juice, and sugar) with pale ale. Yuck. It tasted like crap and cost me a whopping $11. And their draft beer -- of which they have a rather small and shitty selection -- is $6 a pint! 

While the dance floor was fun and boasted some fantastic throwback 90's tunes, I won't be back again unless it's for another birthday party -- this place is actually great for large groups -- but even then it will probably be begrudgingly.
author: Tiffany S.

description: This seems like the kind of place you'd end up if you'd already been to a couple other bars first. It was extremely crowded on a Friday night. I might try to come back when it's less crazy.
author: Julia D.

description:
I finally made it out to the new location. I've been to the OG JC a couple times before, and it was always a good place to grab a drink, talk and lounge out. The new spot is a lot bigger, but I'm unsure if they've used the space to best fit their traffic. 

Getting there at 5:30pm on Friday night, it was already too crowded for my liking. Then 30 minutes later...BOOM...ridiculously packed. I'm pretty sure I impregnated both women and men in trying to squeeze-walk through the crowds (I actually gave some dude an accidentally over the jeans rub when I picked up my bag). The bartenders were nice, but kind of slow especially for the amount of people there.

I'd come back. But only on a Mon-Thurs 4:30-6pm time frame. Come the crowds, it was no longer fun.
author: Jon C.

description:
So I came here on a friday with some friends. I really liked the space cuz it has a bar, a small dance floor and some comfy couches to chill at, but I only liked one drink; The "sweet Leilani" it was a delicious concoction of sake with passion fruit and i don't really know what else but damn, it was good. 

 I also tried their basil gin gimlet which tasted just like lime juice, not good. Also, something called "red headed slut" or something like that, it was gross...way too sweet. 
The music was chill but not great, definitely a place to stop by just for that one drink or a beer especially cuz there's no-cover and then move on. Maybe I'll give it another shot another time to see if it's better on a different night. For now it's just ok.
author: Ireri L.

description: Came here on Friday and Saturday nights..No Cover! Drinks range $8-10.. and there is a dance floor.. I liked the Friday night music better, more hip hop and r&b music and I loved that they played old school hip hop and r&b too!! Saturday, they mixed in more latin flavor and salsa music.  Downer is the bathroom..it's unisex, with everyone lining up behind each other..
author: Mimi P.

description:
The bouncer out front is wack and thought I had a fake ID, but other than that, I love this bar!  Always the go-to spot near work that we can all meet up after a long day.  The drinks are all really delicious too.  

Prices are pretty normal for bars in that area.  8/9 long islands.  

Might also be relevant that when you first enter the bar, there's an open space on the right side that has sometimes been used as a small private happy hour area.  Definitely a great spot to hang.  I think it's mostly work crowd since it's near so many offices.
author: Anna T.

description: there's a bouncer (a friendly one) to greet you as you entered into a jammed packed mob of friendly faces. DJ/Music is cool but the dance 'area' is a bit small. there's two VIP seatings in the back. I absolutely LUV the pitbulls art pieces, gorgeous! it can get very stuffy so leave your jackets in the car. There's a private area upstairs...i am thinking about hosting our next company HH there!
author: Vee V.

description:
The very first time I came to JCs was when it was at it's original location and I liked it right away.  I enjoyed the atmosphere...it's one of those really cool chill spots where you feel comfortable no matter what you're wearing or which party you're with.  But man was it crowded!! Resulting in a huge line for the two co-ed bathrooms...and when I say co-ed, I also mean used by some couples as a "bonding" room ;0)

Well, not much has changed at it's new location...or maybe it just feels that way because where they have slipped in some areas, they have gained in others.  

It's not as comfortable to just pull on the old pair of jeans and tee and head out the door because somehow it feels like that's just not a good idea (damn! that's one of the things I really enjoyed about it - slip!).  
Now there's a designated dance floor/area where I can get my groove on...and it's separate from the bar area (gain!).  
I think the new place demoted me points or something cause it takes that much longer for me to get a drink unless I'm with a group that knows the bartender (pouting face - slip!).  
The bartenders are still very much heavy handed because I never leave this place completely sober...ever!! (gain!)  
Mixed goldfish, pretzels, and the like with my alcohol?! (gain! teehee)
Still have long lines for the, now, three co-ed bathrooms (slip!), but haven't witnessed any "bonding" time from couples occupying them (gain!...no, slip!...no, gain!...hmm...??? LOL)

I have never been upstairs...because, actually, I didn't even know there was one.  
I was introduced to the head bartender one visit and he was very pleasant!  He even introduced me to the owner!...very cool! =)

I'll always come to JCs cause it's still a cool chill spot...jus slightly different...and further down the street! =)
author: Ninja H.

description:
I love the vibe at John Collins.  The place is intimate and plays great music.  The best part -- NO COVER all night!

I came here with some girlfriends and we danced the night away.  It was so much fun.  They play hip/hop and top 40.  They throw in a few oldies here and then and that really gets the crowd going.

I like the location too as there are plenty of places to park and it's not too dangerous to walk to from your car.  I'll def be back when I'm ready for another night out in the City.
author: Jenn G.

description:
Great bar to kick it.  Good music (top 40/sometimes hip hop), chill atmosphere, and affordable drinks.  

Pros:
- plenty of parking in the nearby lot
- no pretentious doormen
- no cover, no line

Cons:
- can get pretty crowded on Saturday nights
author: Kat G.

description:
John Colins recently moved from its old location on Natoma Street to this spot. The new location is waaaay bigger than the old one with far more seating, but it still has that same great liquor selection.  I seem to recall the bartenders making better drinks than I've recently had at this location, but that might be because my standards are now higher.

Their website says, "Dress code strictly enforced. No baggy jeans, long t-shirts or sports gear allowed."  This is likely due to the fact that this spot is for some inexplicable reason a huge douchebag magnet. Maybe this is because John Colins subscribes to what I personally believe to be the ridiculous policy of having to pay to reserve a table since it includes bottle service. What If I don't want bottle service? What if I want to drink what I like to drink and my friends and I would have spent far more than your table reservation fee but now you'll never know? However, you can usually just show up early and stake out a table or area near the front of the bar, which also keeps you reasonably isolated from the d-bags that show up after 9pm.

If you want to reserve a table table, they run $50-100 depending if you want a 3-8 person table or 4-10 person table since any table reservation will include a bottle of sparkling wine.  They also have private rooms at the new space that run $500 (15-person room downstairs) or $1000 (30-person room upstairs) with a private bar and a bar minimum (I was too scared to ask what this was), which all include bottle service.  You'll need to give them a credit card to hold the reservation.  

Happy Hour Special 5-7pm: $1 off EVERYTHING
author: Kristina A.

description:
Your standard bar in the fidi/soma area.
Plus is a small dance floor and good music.
Head to the window to the left of the bar for faster ordering.
author: Noah P.

description: I think this bar is pretty sick. The band playing the night I went did a lot of great hip hop and soul covers which make for great stand and drink music in my opinion. I also really like the big paintings of the pitbulls, if only there were some real ones to pet while I  get my drank on.
author: Misha T.

description:
Change is the only thing you can bank on in this crazy world. The old John Colins was a special place that seemed to defy classification and bring an eclectic mix of folks. The new John Colins doesn't quite capture the same charm of the old brick building location. I think a decade of breaking the place in might do nicely.

I've been here a few times and each subsequent trip gets better. When this place gets crowded, the bar area can be a complete and total clusterfuck. Thankfully they employ some really great cocktail waitresses who can help the front area acquire their libations in a most civilized manor.

All in all, this is a decent bar to throw a party or attend an after-work gathering. Bring a high energy and you'll have a good time.
author: Christopher K.

description:
Came here with a bunch of people for my girlfriends birthday. When we got there, the girls went in while the guys decided to hangout for a bit outside.

Once we decided to go in, the bouncer held us in line saying us guys can't go in without girls. Even after explaining to him that all 15 girls we were with went in two minutes before us. I asked when we were going to be let in and I didn't even get an answer. He was even letting in people behind us who were with girls. After about twenty minutes of waiting, we call the girls outside and left to go to another bar.

Good job John Colins! You left the girls inside, who were waiting for us guys outside to buy them drinks. Since it was my girlfriends Bday, there was a lot of $ to be spent ...too bad we ended up spending it Stefs down the street.
author: Gary K.

description:
John Colins is a new lounge that opened up near 2nd and mission. They have a tropical theme to their place. Happy hour is packed with local business people (so don't even think about finding a place to sit at 6pm).

My company had a happy hour there last week and we were smart enough to start at 5pm.  Pretty soon the place was packed with engineers, office monkeys and secretaries sucking down lychee-tinis and red headed sluts (that's one potent drink!).

Overall its a great place to catch up with some friends after work. Be sure to check out the original artwork on the walls - it's a nice touch
author: Huyness D.

description:
My avoidance of SOMA has gone long and deep for reasons that I probably shouldn't disclose.  But, I went to this place in SOMA for a friend's bday this past Saturday, and it was the bomb!  A nice, classy, dimly lit open space, with a conveniently placed bar and nice lounging area in the back.  

The place has some amazing art, and had a DJ spinnin some awesome beats from the 90s that evening. There was even a place to dance!  I've heard it gets really crowded but we were there on Pride Saturday, so everyone was up and about in the Castro, so it was just the right amount of peeps.  Love it!  Awesome vibe, will be back again. :)
author: Megha S.

description:
What a nice place to get some drinks with friends.  A group of us were here on an uncrowded Thursday night.  However, I was told it gets packed on weekends.  There was a good band playing some chill music.  Compared to LA bars, prices were reasonable -- most cocktails are $9 to $11 (prices in LA-LA Land would run about $3 more).

If you like strong drinks, I recommend the 007 Vesper Martini.  It was on the specials menu, though, so it might not be available all the time.  For something lighter and refreshing, go for the Dark & Stormy.

Note there's a $20 minimum for credit card purchases.  This can be easily reached with 2 drink orders.
author: Art M.

description:
Ive been here twice and both times were completely different. First time I came on a Friday night with two of my girl friends from LA. No cover They played some good hip hop music. The crowd was diverse and after awhile it became pretty crowded by the end of the night. All in all, my girls really liked this place. 

Second time was TOTALLY different. Came in around 1130p, again no cover, but the crowd and music was not what I expected. They were playing some sort of latin music. Crowd wise it was pretty empty for being still kind of early. We only stayed for one drink and left. 

I had a great time here the first time so I'd definitely come back here on a Friday night.
author: Rochelle I.

description:
John Colins could very quickly become one of my favorites...  I feel like I'm the only person on earth (or at least in San Francisco) who hasn't been to John Colins; I don't know what I've been doing the last few months!  Anyway, the place is laid-back and casual but cool (how could any place in SoMa have UNexposed brick?).  Maybe I'm old but any place that plays old school hip hop (music and videos!), is easy to get a drink (and at a resonable price), has no line, has seating, isn't too crowded and has a good, mixed crowd is an AWESOME place.  The bartenders are also nice eye candy.  :-)

Too bad the Osha Thai Noodle next door closes (relatively) early...  Boo.
author: Wendy L.

description:
I went here on a Saturday evening. I liked it, it wasn't too crowded. It was a small and narrow space, but it didn't feel that way (maybe cuz of the high ceilings). It has brick walls and really unique and nice artwork. And they played a few random videos on their screen (placed above the doorway).

We sat by the bar, at a table that had the booth side (against the wall) and some small stools on the other side.

The drinks were strong! The bartenders were nice and so where the bouncers.

I ordered a Rum Colins, and the bartender must have heard Tom Colins...it wasn't great. Then, when i went to ask another bartender to add some lime in my drink, and he recommended...the "dark and stormy"...which has ginger beer in it. It was different and pretty strong. I don't know if I'd order it again...I like ginger, but it was hard to get used to in this drink.

The DJ's booth was upstairs, didn't get to go upstairs, but it looked like a small space.

The crowd was pretty chill and pretty diverse. After a while it started to get packed and we left.

It was a nice bar, but kinda cold inside. (but i guess that's good if it gets crowded...so it doesn't get too stuffy.)
author: N C.

description:
I LOVE THIS JOINT! Seriously, it's my new favorite bar in San Francisco. Couches, a DJ, a huge bar with smokin' hot bartenders.. what else could a girl ask for on any given night? A lot of the white collared crowd in SOMA will flock here after work hours for a quick drink with friends during happy hour. If you check in here, you always get $1 off any drink. Located in an obscure spot, this place has to be my favorite hidden gem! If the afore mentioned isn't enough to get you down there, I don't know what will!

GO HERE!
author: Tisha G.

description: The Asian bouncer with the long hair was extremely rude. He said a lot of racist comments and even called someone a cracker to their face. That is terrible. He was about to fight some kid I guess because he is a hothead. They were arguing and suddenly the Asian bouncer with the long hair spit on his shoes and the kid threw a punch and ran away as the bouncer tried to fight him. I saw the whole thing go down and I just left because the bouncer might spit at me. Don't come to this joint--trashy employees.
author: Marlon T.

description:
I was a huge fan of the old John Colins and I'm even more of a fan now! Though this place does get a bit loud as it starts to fill up, which takes all of 45 minutes after most get off work and head over. The space is much bigger, a bit more swankier, and the drinks are just as strong and deliscious! Great for grabbing a drink after work, meeting up for a pre-dinner drink on a date or just coming out on a Saturday night with the girls (there's some very nice looking gentleman that frequent this place...just sayin).

p.s. there's absolutely no cell phone service inside the place (at least for AT&T customers)
author: Kristy M.

description:
Admittedly, there's a lot of attributes that would normally make me like John Collins--dark woods, brick walls, overall pretty classic. However, the negative outweigh the positives! Crowded and muggy space, funky music, and rude bouncer(s) are why John Collins deserves 3 stars. 

I ventured out to JC on a Saturday around 11:30pm. Awesome that there's no cover and virtually no dress code. No line as well, so we step right in. Once inside, it's packed. I find my group of friends and proceed to people watch, and grab drinks at the bar. Chill ambiance, decent vibe. The bartenders are nice enough, serving the masses as quickly and as efficiently as they can. 

After being there for over 30 minutes, my friends and I notice the space is muggy. (I fear the extra moisture will make my hair begin to frizz!) To escape the mugginess, a friend and I decide to walk around to do more people watching.  After snaking through the crowd, we find there is practically no one dancing on the "dance floor." Perhaps it was the poor music selection. No 80's, 90's, not even top 40's or classic renditions of anything danceable. With the exception of an MJ song, the music was a bust! 

45 minutes now pass and the crowd seems to be thinning. Perhaps the masses evenly dispersed themselves throughout the venue, or JC was simply a "first stop of the night" type of venue. In any case, almost midnight and around 7 of the guys in our group have yet to join us inside. The bouncer wouldn't let them in because "there were too many guys inside." Not even the pleading birthday girl's story broke the bouncer (her bf was one of the guys outside). It's one thing to say that they aren't letting ANYONE in because it's too crowded, but another to single out the guys specifically.  If this were Vegas, this would be understandable, but John Collins is a tiny bar lounge that in my opinion has no real cache (yet anyway) to shun guys like that. 

So, we leave...all 25 or so of us. 

John Collins I wanted to like you...especially since I enjoyed the old location for happy hour.  However, you fell way short of my expectations (which were probably too high to begin with). Too bad, so sad.
author: Marie B.

description:
If I was just walking by, and not meeting friends, I would have no idea this place existed. From the outside, it looks like some underground art show in the back alley of the Academy. But alas, you walk in and find a cool, basement like bar with DJs spinning good music, interesting art on the walls, tasty drinks (try the Paloma...my favorite Squirt and Tequila in funky mason jars) and a good people watching crowd. 

The only problem with this place is by 9pm it was empty. Definitely a place to go on the first leg of bar hopping or to catch a drink with co-workers.

Hint: there is a red bucket at the back part of the bar where you will find self-serve goldfish and pretzels for to quell the grumbly stomachs. You're welcome tummies!
author: Molly W.

description:
Aaaaaahh heelllz yeeeaah.

Went here last minute for my birthday with 25 of my closest friends.  It was a Saturday night so we weren't sure what to expect.  We had also ended up there the night before and told the fellow at the door (I cannot remember his name...and I keep trying...starts with an S) that we would be bringing a group, but that was the extent of our reservation.

Saturday night:
9:00pm
We arrive and there's no cover.  We had been told there wouldn't be, but once you've spent some time inside, it seems like a place that would (but please don't start...please).

Drinks are very reasonably priced and they show up in your hand surprisingly quickly.  So quickly in fact, that I don't even remember ordering whatever number I must have drank to feel the way I did the next morning.

By the end of the night, the whole group was hanging out upstairs in the room with the DJ (I call it the "VIP Room" when I'm telling people who didn't come to make them feel like they missed out).

This place is awesome and I think I'll be spending a lot more money here...but not too much.
author: Zak D.

description:
I think this place is a hit or miss.  You either hit a great night with cool peeps or you miss with a lot of "DB's" trying to cut a rug on the dancefloor.  The latter was my last experience at JC's.

My girls and I came in to have an after-bday-dinner drink.  The place was still a bit lively (it was around 9:30 or so...) so I guess it was transition time between happy hour and late hour...whatever time it was, it was ugly hour.  The only thing that was making up for the ugliness were the bartenders...*Enter: Hangover reference, "He was the BAR-tender"*

I think you definitely have to come with a big group of people to enjoy this place...I've come here on many other occasions (happy hour) and had a blast.  I'll definitely update soon...Sorry, JC.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
John Colins ... the name is perfect.  It sounds like the name of a friend who lives in a nice place in the right part of the city that you're going to stop off at to get drinks before heading out to party.  That's exactly what this place is like!  

Despite a pretty diverse crowd and a reasonable number of people milling about - I was always served rather quickly at the bar .  They had some movie playing ... I think Scarface? ... though last time I was there, they were showing some kung fu how-to videos.  Maybe next time I'll suggest showing "best of" scenes ... I mean honestly, who wouldn't be ready to get down after seeing the gun scene from the first Matrix?

Anyway, thanks for having us over John!  I'll see you soon!
author: Kathleen W.

description:
The funny thing about John Collins is that i ACTUALLY went here before. i must have been really buzzed or something, because a year ago i attended my friend's friend party at Zebulon  and i ran across the street to John Collins. However, last time the place was SUPER crowded and they didn't let guys in only if they were accompany with a girl. But last Saturday, John Collins was better -- less crowded and the drinks were really cheap.  My friends and i ordered -- 1 Mojoito (REALLY GOOD), 1 shot of Henny, 1 shot of Goose, and 2 Goose Tonics = $30.00 without tip. YES REALLY CHEAP. 

The crowd was pretty laid back, some people were dressed up but others were just wearing jeans or one guy wore a Giants jersey and shorts! That night the DJ played 80's music, plus they were also showing Poison's concert on the ceiling. Who knew Bret Michaels was such a hottie back then. just kidding. The bathrooms were clean minus 1 star for the fact there are only 1 stall for womens and the line becomes really long especially if one drunken girl is taking her dang time. 

I would definitely come back to John Collins when its NOT so crowded.
author: Carol Y.

description: Played a gig there on a Tuesday night and they took very good care of us. Had a clean green room ready and waiting with proper amenities. Staff was friendly and helpful and the crowd was having a great time drinking and dancing.  Definitely a cool place!
author: Michael S.

description:
I've only been here a few times and never during the peak weekend nights when it might get super crowded, but I've never had a problem getting into the place, never had a problem getting drinks, and always have a good time.  

The bartenders here are pretty cool and are always willing to answer your questions about their huge liquor selection.  The crowd here is a little bit more mature meaning you won't get those clowns who still insist on ordering long island iced teas or any other concoction that pretty much guarantees a hangover the next morning.

Overall a very cool place.  The only thing that sucks is the area is pretty congested due to its location and the amount of places to go in the vicinity so parking can be a miserable situation.
author: JP T.

description: Nice bar with a good vibe. Lots of comfy seating and space to hang out, talk with friends. The drinks are well made and tasty, though I mainly stuck with whiskey so it didn't take much skill. The $20 minimum for CC was a little annoying, but other than that I really enjoyed the place. Nothing remarkable, but seems like a reliable spot to go for a drink
author: Vinitha R.

description:
Great happy hour, and nice bartenders. I love it when they have a DJ because they usually have great music playing. The atmosphere at this new place is swankier than the previous location on Natoma (though I loved that location too). 

There's free Chex mix at the end of the bar, and they have 151 (which means Galvatrons!). There are three distinct areas in which you can chill. Four if they little room by the bathroom is open. Five if you can go upstairs (I've never been up there, and don't know if it's actually open to the public).

This place is crackin sometimes. Get here early!

NOTE: If you plan to meet up with friends here, let them know beforehand, ESPECIALLY if you have AT&T and/or an iPhone. There's NO service until you walk to 2nd St.
author: Louis N.

description:
I gotta say, I like the new digs. In a way, the atmosphere is the same as their first location (see my old review), but somehow it's different, and a lot more open as well. There's a side room as well, so even during the cluster f*ck happy hours that seem to be de rigeur in SOMA and the Fi-Di these days, you still might be able to manage some breathing room. 

They have given up on some of the seating, so it's perhaps a bit more bar than lounge, but if you can snag a few seats at the bar, you're golden. JC 2.0 has re-earned a spot on my rotation!
author: Nish N.

description:
No cover! Great bar and lounge with a small dance floor to enjoy the good music. Be sure to dress "nice-er" and come early because there is a "dress code." 

Don't use the bathroom because the line is super long (guys and girls wait on 3 individual bathrooms). And ordering drinks can take forever with a huge crowd. Still, 4 stars for no cover, great location, dance area, and cool chillout vibe.
author: Chester A.

description:
Awesome spot tucked neatly away off of 2nd St., right around from Osha.

Came here right after a birthday dinner on a Sat night, so we got into the bar relatively early and beat some of the crowds.  However, that worked out great for us, since we got to claim some seats to kick off the night's "festivities".  Besides our group, there was still a decent number of people inside, and I was definitely enjoying the feel here - nothing pretentious but not too relaxed...just a good vibe all around.  Drinks were poured by a friendly bartender who knew what she was doing, and the DJ upstairs played a good mix of songs for us to drink to.

I do wonder (worry?) how this place can get when it gets busier though, but I definitely see myself coming back.
author: Mike L.

description:
New John Collins is almost likeable. I like the upscale feel with the dark wood and classy high ceilings, but the place itself is like an optical illusion- it looks so big inside but the center walkway through the bar is always crowded with people so I'm always looking to go into a less crowded side room but the doors just lead outside... to the street.  There is one offset room with a DJ and an upstairs room that looks down on the bar scene and seems like it can be reserved for parties.

I've been here 3 times so far (missed HH everytime, damn the EB BART commute) and the music is always too loud.  It's ok for one drink, but 9pm on a Wednesday is not clubbing hours.  

I like the mixed drinks but they can be pretty pricey.  My favorite thing here is the mixed pretzels and goldfish that hit the spot as we usually skip dinner and just head straight to meet friends at the bar.
author: Holly B.

description: Just a heads up - don't try to book a party here. I thought I had booked a reception, then they sold out the entire bar from underneath us. Not professional and not very good business practice. Shame on you.
author: piems s.

description:
Four stars for having FRIENDLY doormen/bouncers...for not having a ridiculously long line (for no good reason - see Hartot review) and for hopefully KICKING HARLOT'S ass in business.

Minus a star for the not-so-great music.  

My party of ... many ... stayed for only a few minutes, but I will definitely be coming back.  This place is intimate, yet SOMA chill...
author: Helen F.

description: I was looking for a good spot to take some friends in from out of town who wanted to dance to hip hop & not wait in line. John Colins delivered on both orders! Good diverse crowd for a Saturday night. Drinks were fairly easy to get & the bartenders were friendly. Even though the dance floor is on the smaller side, it fits a decent sized crowd. I will definitely be back when I'm in need of a fun night out of dancing!
author: Mel A.

description: I don't think there is a $20 min on charges like the other reviews said.  This place is hard to find b/c it's not marked.  It's a long narrow bar with some sitting areas and a small, congested dance floor to the right when you walk in.  Earlier in the night they played Zumba-type of music.  Later it was hip-hop.  Mixed crowd.  Mostly minorities (Asian, African-Americans, Latinos).  Cheaper drinks than Harlot down the street and there's no cover.  Interesting place, but wouldn't go back unless my friends wanted to.  Parking was hard to find but we managed to get a good spot near the Academy of Art.
author: Chris L.

description:
My new favorite after work spot!

The service is great, the seating area in the back is cozy yet open, and the crowd is friendly. I thoroughly enjoyed my experience, and my Stella, at John Colins. I brought my visiting friend from Michigan here as well as a work buddy, and the 3 of us enjoyed our conversation and drinks- mind you, we arrived right at 5 as they opened. It got pretty busy around 7, so we headed to destination #2. 

Definitely come here! The doorman is also great- he laughed at the 5 of us all making a run for the door to try and pick up AT&T service- always a downtown San Francisco fail.
author: Kristin F.

description:
My experiences here constantly swing between 5 stars and 1 star; hence the 3 stars.  For example, I've had nights where I've have an amazing time with friends and strangers alike, while on the other hand, I've walked out of the place with friends because we couldn't get drinks in a timely fashion. 

The see-sawing continues--great atmosphere, but on some nights it's so quiet you can hear conversations at the other end of the bar, and on others, the lousy dj's tracks make your head spin in pain.  Drinks are likewise, as prices are a tad bit higher than would be expected for this place; I don't think their cocktails are special in anyways.  Yet, they have posted drink specials that are reasonable if you're looking to get drunk.

Play Russian Roulette and give these guys a try!
author: Sam W.

description:
I've gone to the old location several times when I used to work in the area.  This was my first time at the new location.  It definitely has a similar feel but with the addition of a dance floor.  Overall a good experience but I noticed that people seemed to be a lot pushier here than other bars.  It really started to die down at what didn't seem like too late.  Good ambiance and fun with the right group of friends.  

I noticed a taco bar strategically parked right outside the entrance on my way in and hoped it would be there on the way out, but it wasn't. :-(  It was also interesting to see the mob of people that lined up to use the three bathrooms lol.
author: Christopher W.

description:
3.25 will go again.

so we were tryna hit this one place, but it was closed to the general public. doorman let us know about mr. collins...and there we went.

walked up to the bar and the first thing bartender says is that we can have three drinks. we say aiite, cool, take our drinks (after tipping!) and sit down. few minutes later a server comes around with free shots!

well. you can imagine what i think of this place. definitely going to come back for more!
author: Alvin D.

description: I use to frequent this place quite often when my friend was single and on the prowl. I don't know why she chose such small venue to go looking for her next boo thang...but it always ended in disappointment. I mean what do you expect when you go to a venue with a "lounge area" smaller than my living room and the dance floor is smaller than my dining room? The only good thing about this place is that there's no cover...but get here too late and you'll have to wait in the line. Also, the bartenders are hit or miss. Some of them were super awesome but some of them were super not awesome. Drinks are reasonably priced, but I doubt I'd make the trip all the way up to SF to come here. I probably won't be coming back anytime soon as my friend has been happily in a relationship for the past year; and I pray to the lord it lasts so I don't have to step foot into this place again.
author: Lisa T.

description:
Chill and clean - Just the way I like my bars. 

I went to John Collins for happy hour after work one day. I'm new to the San Francisco happy hour/bar scene, so I have no expectations. 

I enjoyed a nice amber beer at the recommendation of the bartender, followed by a basil gin gimlet, which was very refreshing. Also, who doesn't like free pretzels and goldfish to go with your alcoholic beverage? Hooray for something to munch on! $1 off your first drink for 'checking in' wasn't so bad either. 

The decor was pretty simple. All we needed were some comfortable seating to hang out. We sat in the back, where there were some ottomans and cushioned benches. It was a comfortable setting for us to chat and enjoy our drinks. I loved the enormous paintings of the dogs on the walls, also!

I can't say anything about the later evening crowded evening scene, but as for the post-work time, I can't complain.
author: Sarah G.

description:
A bunch of my friends and I went here for two of our girlfriends' birthdays.  We got a table in the far back of the bar, enough seats for some people to relax and mingle.  The music was great and the drinks were great too.  We had some bad mojitos (tasted like 60% club soda) but when we complained, they remade them and they tasted much better.  

The birthday girls made some treats (strawberry dipped chocolates, madelines, pretzels, etc) and brought them into the club.  

The decor is great, awesome crowd, upbeat hostess, and nice bouncers (always a big plus for me).  The only bad thing was that parking was a bitch but I got lucky and found a spot less than a block away after circling the area several times.
author: Phuong H.

description:
Maybe it was the fact that it was someone's music video release party.  Or maybe it was the fact I paid money to be around crazies.  I don't know - maybe I have bad judgement sometimes when I want to have fun. All I know is that this place was the last place even the devil would visit on a romp around town.

Besides the emptiness of the place and random people dancing by themselves in a corner (when no one was dancing and not really any music was playing) we had to endure (we only stayed for 25 minutes) poor bar service.  The bartenders refused to listen to my friends and I when we ordered our drinks.  RUM and coke - how hard is that?  Captain and coke - nope, not much harder.  What did we get?  WHISKEY and coke.  After explaining to him that this was not RUM, he apologized and immediately made us a new drink - another WHISKEY and coke.  Again, after we explained this to him and his friend, Muscles McGhee - the other bartender, they rolled their eyes and proceeded to make our drinks- WHISKEY again; we shouted, "NO, NOT WHISKEY-RUM!!" Those magical light bulbs finally went off in the heads and they smiled, apologized and proceeded to try and make a rum and coke.  However, they realized that they were out of rum.  How in the world does a bar run out of rum at 9:30 pm on a Friday night??? 

I mean, I know that maybe they didn't restock from Thursday, but really?  Also, HOW did they not hear us asking for rum the first 2 TIMES??  It wasn't even crowded.  They had some top shelf rum that they found after searching for a while that was only half a bottle so they made it for us.  It was more coke than rum, but whatever.  Since it seemed to be an off-night and they were more concerned with talking to each other, that's cool. You can't expect everyone to do their job well. . . . 

Anyway, maybe we will try "hitting the town again" when I am back in SFO, but I'm going to try a different bar that won't take my money at the door and then promptly slap me across the face like an insolent child.

Worst bar.  By far.  In SFO.
author: Susan L.

description:
Wandering in with a bunch of co-workers after a holiday party.  The dance music pumping.  We yell to order whatever beverage comes to mind.
A pint of an IPA arrives in my hand.
We all yell to each other to talk.  A band sets up on the small stage ahead of us.
The glow sticks a friend brought somehow get passed around to others and even up the the woman setting up on stage.
Look at the watch.  Think, ahh, it's not too late yet.
The music changes to the band which is also electronica-based as the previous iPod dance medley booming as we entered.
Time passes and I take a cab home.
Where was that place?
author: Kev M.

description:
Im a bit mixed on this one...

Pros: Modern, chic space. Parking isn't too horrible in this area either. Had a house sangria during happy hour and it was meticulously prepared by hand and topped with fresh fruit. 

Cons: No food or appetizers on the menu :( the happy hour is limited and expensive compared to other places on the city. Can't comment on John Colins as a nightclub, but I can imagine it being a great space.
author: Mariela D.

description:
Another cool bar in SF.  The place seems fairly nice and clean which is rare for a bar.  Probably more so since they're at their newer location.  

I've only come here after work.  If you stay at work too late, then it may be crowded when you get here.  If you sneak out of work early, then you'll be golden as the place won't be too packed yet.  

Definitely worth checking out sometime if you're in the area.
author: Patrick L.

description:
Yikes!!!! This new location is so hip, it's practically impossible to wedge in at happy hour on a Friday. I think you'd have to show up around 5 pm to stake out a seat.

Drinks are on the spendier side, but STIFF.

Total sausage fest. Douche-y crowd. 

No AT&T/iPhone service inside, so you'll have to go outside to send drunk texts.
author: Lauren H.

description: Love its new location...same great bar..but lots more room!
author: Mimi T.

description:
I like this spot. They have nice decor, play cool music and there's a few TVs with sports always on.  Who doesn't like a nice clean and decorated bar with sports?!  There's also sofas, chairs and bar stools for anyone and everyone to sit down (mind you without having "bottle service" or being VIP.  Not sure how I ever lasted at the clubs and doubt I'll ever go back to the club scene knowing that there are fantastic bars/lounges in San Francisco like John Colins.

My first drink was not a regular drink.  They don't usually make Pisco Sours, but the bartender who helped me knew what a traditional Pisco Sour was - even though I didn't know what was in it - and made something close enough to it, if not better!  Later I found out that my bartender was John himself of John Colins.   I am removing one star because he had to leave before 9 and passed the recipe onto a younger bartender.  This bartender was an amateur and somehow managed to ruin my drink. It was seriously gross, but a different bartender (taller light black guy) was able to mix something up and save the drink.  

Anyway, how lucky was I that I had a celebrity (John) make my drink!!! I'll definitely be back again but picky next time of my bartenders.  No noobs!
author: Dee H.

description: I have been coming here for years and have to say it's one of my favorites for fidi happy hour! The venue is beautiful, crowd is good, bartenders are always really nice and owners are very sweet. I help with a non-profit and approached them about donating and they were super generous and supportive. They are all about the community and great crew of people!! GO HERE!! :)
author: Nicole P.

description:
I went here for the first time last Friday. What a great place. The drinks were a perfect mix of flavor and alcohol...I really enjoyed the ambiance of part bar, part night club. The DJ was playing some great mixes, prefect for a Friday night wind-down. 

One of the key points that I really liked about this place, was the fact that the staff was really nice. Whenever I went to the bar, it was pretty easy to get my order in. The waitress who was floating around the floor always seemed to be around when we needed her to bring another drink. It was just great. 

My only recommendation is that there are not enough bar stools in the front area of the restaurant which made it uncomfortable to hang out with a larger group for an extended period of time. 

I will absolutely go here again.
author: Marissa C.

description:
Oh my, my, my....can't say enough about this place.  Awesome energy, fun bartenders and a lot of fun people.  

I'm going to frequent on a regular.  :)
author: Michael J.

description:
This is a cool place: 
to come after happy hour at 111 Minna
to come for pre-drinking when clubbing on the weekend
to come if you are bar/club hopping in the area (Fluid, 111 Minna, Harlot, some Irish bar around the corner, etc.)

Bouncer and bartenders are nice and approachable.  There is a diverse crowd here, so you never know what  you're gonna get.  So far, I've met a lot of out-of-towners and local party/business people. 

There's cool mellow house music in the background, but it's not a dancing place.  Come here only to chill and lounge.
author: Debbie N.

description:
I have been to this place a few times.  When going on a Thursday or Friday around 5-9pm it was rockin' and had a good time.  Drinks were strong and reasonably priced.  There are not a lot of places to sit, or they are already occupied so plan on standing. 

The other time I went was on a weeknight around 10ish and the place was mostly dudes it seemed like. It just made the ambiance seem kind of gay with too many dudes hanging around.  On top of that they were showing some porn from the 50's on the wall.  

A solid 4 stars for Th-Fr happy hour and 2 for weeknight evenings, avg out to 3 stars.  There are a few other bars and restaurants in close proximity though if its not happening.
author: James H.

description: I had the pleasure of hanging out with some great peeps here for the beginning of a birthday get together.  Since the crew wanted to stake out a space in the lounge area, we showed up at 9:30p to occupy half of the back lounge - it ended up being around fifteen of us comfortably in that corner.  At the start, the place was empty and I got a good look around.  There are two large pit bull paintings mounted on the back end of the linear, brick-walled space.  The bar is decently stocked.  Exclusive of the gratis drinks I had from the birthday crew, the four (Maker's Mark, Jameson, well rum & Coke, Sierra Nevada Pale Ale) I had were $21 without tip.  Shortly thereafter it got crowded.  It became Asian central.  Just sayin.  A very attractive Asian central.  It's probably a great happy hour and first stop of the night spot.
author: Darren S.

description:
my girlfriends and i came here for happy hour drinks on a friday night. it took us about 20 minutes to find the place because it's not directly on the main street. it's sort of down an alleyway and off to the side on 2nd. when we finally arrived, we were so mad at the lack of help from our iPhones' Maps that we went big and started out with the very thing that could lead to a ridiculously crazy night... tequila shots. to. the. face.

oohwee. those $5 shots done did it. the happy hour deals were too good to pass up! the bartenders were friendly and the crowd was chill. the venue is pretty nice too, but a bit small. i can't imagine this place being very fun when it's packed with people, so thankfully we were early and avoided the crowd. 

a couple of (secretly strong) drinks later, at the end of the night, we somehow ended up down at sloane on 12th and howard and danced our bootys off. john you da man!
author: Caitlin C.

description: Crowded, hot, and pretentious, arrogant, and rude doormen.! Plenty of better options in the area to check out. AVOID AVOID AVOID.
author: Ferdinand B.

description:
John Colins is HANDS-DOWN MY FAVORITE BAR in the CITY!!! Oh John Colins, how I miss you so....I use to work 2 blocks away, so it was easily accessible on weekdays for Happy Hour. But now, when I do make it out there, it is my first pick out of 111 Minna, Zebulon, and 83 Proof which are all within the same vicinity.

Pros:
*NO COVER
*NO DRESS CODE
*STRONG DRINKS at reasonable prices--my fav is the Lychee Martini topped off with a pretty orchid! Free pretzels and cheese goldfishes also! 
*GREAT AMBIANCE: Love the red brick walls, pitbull paintings, and upper Dj level which you can get some dancing action on. If you get there early enough, you can snag some coaches and ottomans to sit on. 
*GREAT CROWD: Young, hip professionals and mixed crowd. More guy to girl ratio, sorry fellas. This place is normally packed, and although you will get shoved around from time to time, people actually apologize. And girls, you don't have to worry about slimy d-bags trying to approach you b/c most of the guys that come here work in the nearby FIDI area and are cordial. 
*AWESOME MUSIC: Ahhh! Love, love the music here!!!! A mix of Hip Hop, Tops 40s, and Old School Hip Hop, and 90's Remixes. The last time I went on a Friday night, DJ Dan was off the hook. He started the night playing some 90's throwback with MJ and then started going into the Top 40s: "Meet Me Halfway", "Sexy Chick", "Do You Remember", "Bad Romance", "Replay", "Run This Town", etc! He took requests and kept us dancing until closing! 

Cons:
*Once HH starts at 5-6, it gets PACKED. Elbow to elbow packed. 
*One bathroom for the ladies...BOO!

Can't wait to come back for another dancing rendition!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
OLD JC: Been to the old JC across the street from Zebulon many times before. It was pretty small and crowded up fast, especially on Friday/Saturday nights. 

NEW JC: Big improvement. Located just a few blocks up from the Old JC. This location has more space, looks a lot more trendier, and now has a dance floor. 

Service: Fast. It gets crowded like all other places, but the bartenders (even the chick bartenders) serve you fast and easy. Prices aren't too steep for drinks & the drinks are nice & strong. To the right of the lounge, there's a waitress that takes your drink orders. Convenient when the place isn't packed. When it does, take your ass to the bar instead. =)

Music: Great music. Hip hop. I like. 

Dress code: No jeans or sports gear. Basically, just look nice!
author: Joy A.

description: John Collins is good for a low-key happy hour on weekdays! If you're looking for a good bar for a Friday or Saturday night, this is your place. The dance floor can get crowded and musty, so beware! Also, sometimes the music isn't hip hop, so check the online calendar.
author: Kat P.

description:
-1 star for the weak drinks
-1 star for the terrible dj

Came here to grab a few drinks after a long week with my friends and decided to do something more bar than clubby. Me, being from the SBay, just differed to the city folks to decide where we end up for the night. We found ourselves at John Collins. No cover was nice and the overall ambiance was well put together and very SF with the brick walls and decor. 

When we arrived we ordered our first set of drinks of hen & coke and vod/ton's and sadly we were served some pretty weak drinks. After we switched bartenders the drinks appeared to be more "generously" poured, so perhaps it was just a poor pick of bartender first time around. 

What I noticed throughout the night was that the crowds came and went like the tide of the sea. Not sure if that's normally the case, but at times I found the bar area rather thin in attendance, which I wasn't used to, especially when trying to eye the crowd for anyone interesting to talk to. 

Last negative part. The DJ. At random parts of the evening, the music would just entirely shut off and would stumble back into a beat. Not sure if the particular night I went, they had a newb DJ, but it surely didn't help with trying to dance around.

I would say, if you're going for a happy hour hangout, this would be a sweet bar, but if you're lookin to go out dancing and grab a few drinks at night, this place would just be a stop through, not the end destination.
author: Chris D.

description:
I went here for a friend's birthday happy hour.  I had nothing to drink before arriving.  I am not an intimidating or particularly handsome man.

I could not, couldn't, was unable to, procure a drink for myself.

I stood at the bar.  I put cash on the bar.  I explained that I only wanted bottled beer (after I heard the bartender complain to another patron that pulling drafts takes longer...completely understandable in my opinion).  

Still, I did not receive service.

Look at my reviews, I do not give out 1 star ratings lightly.

Usually, I also rate ambiance, price etc.  In this case, all that stuff was irrelevant, because I wasn't served.

This place has 4 stars with 500+ reviews, so my thoughts aren't going to really matter, but I will not return to John Collins.
author: Thomas K.

description: I was lucky enough to host a San Francisco Tweet Up at the amazing John Collins.  A few of our Twitter friends from around the world arrived at John Collins around 9:00 PM and were treated like VIP.  We had our own back stage area complete with lounge seating and greeting table.  The staff from the Manager to the organizer, Giovanna were nothing but professional and outstanding to work with.  Special shout out to Bella for making sure we never went thirsty.  What I liked about John Collins is they made us feel special and at the end of the night, we walked away with smiles on our face.  I would highly recommend John Collins to anyone and everyone hands down all the time for a party or special event.
author: Lisa D.

description:
So we're out in SF and this has become our go to place to get your groove on.  It's amazing we even found this place since it moved since the last time we were here, haha.  Luckily we stayed close by at The Palace Hotel, it made stumbling back for the group in our 4 inch heels more bearable. 

The last time we were here there wasn't a dance floor, yippee for dance floors, the music was hopping so despite the unnatural position of my peds in my 4 inch platforms, I danced a storm.  The next night, I snuck in my flip flops for a 2nd wind, hehe.  There's now a 2nd floor that I failed to venture to.  I like the overall decor and the people here are friendly.  I'd come back here, it's become an SF tradition now :-D
author: Mae-Lae L.

description:
Thank you, walking distance to Yelp HQ. 

Thank you, Pear of Panties (pear vodka and champagne, times two). 

Thank you kind, sexy, (straight!), doorman. 

Thank you, much better circulation than Varnish across the alley. 

Thank you, mysterious arrival of cheese pizza. 

Thank you, even more mysterious arrival of a cab when I wanted to go night night.

No thank you, used pantyliner left behind by a very un-ladlylike lass.
author: dawson s.

description:
Stopped in here one night while we were in San Fran for a few drinks before heading back to the hotel. The Bartenders were very friendly and for the most part pretty knowledgeable, although I did have to fill in our bartender on what was in my Zombie (but to give him credit, he knew it was pretty close to a Mai Tai) 

The drinks came out strong and with plenty of garnish. We found a nice little spot near the back to sit down and enjoyed our drinks thoroughly. The atmosphere of the place was dim lit with plenty of art around the walls and comfortable seating galore.

I can honestly say that when were in the neighborhood again, we will more than likely stop by for another drink :)
author: Justin B.

description:
Came here last week with some friends for a celebration.  It's okay, there wasn't anything special about it, except I remember one of the workers walking around handing out  bowls of goldfishes and pretzels.  

The place was pretty packed last Friday.  The drinks were mediocre.  The music was ok.  I think as long as you are with a good group of friends you can make the most of any bar.
author: Michelle L.

description:
***NOW @ 138 MINNA ST.*****
JC is a great SF bar, and it just got a little bigger & better! They moved around the corner to Minna and the space it great, it's roomier but still has the same chill feeling  and reasonably priced drinks it's always has. 
They are now equipped w/ VIP room with a private bathroom in it (great idea) it's a little stuffy in there as it is way inside but close to the dance floor, another new addition! Same great bartenders waiting to serve you with smiling faces they just opened the new spot this week and things are pretty smooth considering I was there on their first Friday night.
author: Courtney D.

description:
3.5 stars

Pros: Cool layout, no line or cover when we went on a Saturday night and nice selection of drinks.

Cons: Was pretty dead for Saturday night at 10 pm, maybe we went too early.

Overall: I could see this place being awesome when it's awesome and lame when it's lame, I guess it just depends on the night.
author: Binh D.

description:
Great Place. 
It's not often I frequent bars... especially bars that don't have half naked boys and disco music. John Collins is the exception. 
The bar itself has a great lay out. Very roomy. Its easy to sit and have a conversation with friends without feeling intruded upon. It has space to move and you are easily able to get to the bar. 
The bar tenders here are friendly and know how to make a decent drink. This seems to be a very after work crowd. Which is great. Everyone is just unwinding and socializing. A great place to meet your straight friends, have a drink and have a laugh.
author: Wes P.

description:
I like this spot - it's cool, attracts an nice crowd and is perfect for happy hour any day of the week.  Also, the drinks as amazing.  They did a great job of making the place look interesting and it has a cool-urban feel to it....it's prefect for San Francisco.  Most of the people who are here are from the Financial District so you can feel very comfortable strolling into the place with a suit on.  They have great unique cocktails (try the Moscow Mule) and they aren't over-the-top expensive.  

Check it out!
author: Ken G.

description: Easy going night out... Not to crowded & fairly easy to get a drink. I like this spot for the nights I don't feel like battling a crowd.
author: Teena Marie T.

description: A pretty cool spot on the edge of the SF Financial district. Easy on the eye with exposed brick and cool photography on the walls. Wouldn't mind coming back to see what else this venue has to offer.
author: Ryan B.

description:
Why is there a totally mangled Snickers wrapper next to my bed?  Why does my purse smell like whiskey?  Crap. Did I remember to grab my credit card after I paid that tab? 

Why did the polo-shirted barkeep think my tab was $4 when it was really $18? Why didn't I keep my mouth shut and let him go with the $4? 

Wait, back up...Did I really drink at an establishment where all the bartenders wore polo shirts? 

So many questions, so few answers. 

But did I have a good time?  Yep. And the bartenders kept hustlin' when I and about 100 of my closest friends suddenly descended upon their establishment. Extra star right there.

So why wouldn't this place be alright by me? It was, indeed!
author: mariah c.

description:
For all the buzz this bar gets, i would not choose to go here again.

It seems like 9/10 tech after events are thrown here, and while the bar is great, the overall space to stand is really limited. It's usually really stuffy and you can not get a cell signal to save your life... not that they can help that.

Overall, out of all the bars ive been to in SF I would definitely not choose to host any event or happy hour here again.
author: Mallory M.

description: Went to the "new" John Collins the other week for my farewell (work) and early birthday celebration.  Love the new location - only a few blocks away from the old one, but much bigger and cozy!  Gotta love that it's super laid back, ton of people and they still don't charge cover - reasonable priced drinks. Nice leather seats/stools and they have pretzels and goldfish in little bowls around the place - girl loves to eat! :) One of my favorite HH places downtown -- oh, and fun glasses as well.
author: Melody T.

description:
They relocated to a new location. It's nice...a bit larger but the crowd is still as douchey as it was before. 

The bartenders took forever and I'm talking the whole "Let me skip you even though you were waiting here way before anyone else but I'm getting confused with people yelling orders into my ear" kind of service.

No real order to the chaos. I'll go back but after happy hour crowd has died down...it's a total clusterf---
author: Jay H.

description:
I love the new John Collins!  It's dark, roomy and pretty.  They did a good job on picking a place not too far away from the original location.  The drinks were a lot stronger than the ones I had at 111 Minna, where I was earlier in the night.  It wasn't packed on a Tuesday night but that meant more seating for my small group.

I think they can make better use of their space and add more seating.  But they might break out more chairs when it's busy.  I'll have to come back on a busier evening for happy hour.
author: Rosalind S.

description: Drinks were strong.  Or maybe, I'm just a lightweight.
author: Dorothy L.

description:
When you walk in, it is a tad snug and you haven't even reached the bar yet. The vibe though is real chill and the drinks are mixed to near perfection. My favorite spot so far is the loft on the second floor that has a decent size skylight and comfy couches all around. The DJ booth spins some good sounds and its worth the decibals to be there. 

Try the John Colin's drink...honey, Henney, tonic, and lemon...mixed just right.
author: Jamie L.

description:
This newly upgraded, John Collins feels like drinking with a secret society. Walking in for the first time last night, it felt like a total bachelor's bungalow and someone would probably bust out in a secret handshake when you least expect it.

The decor here is nice and simple, but in a relaxed and elegant way. The crowd was very laid back and friendly which seems to be the common culture there. The bartenders were cool and knowledgeable and the drinks were nicely concocted - my goose and tonic was made just right.

Overall, the place was pretty big, the bar section was packed, but there were plenty of seats in the lounge area. You could tell that there were tons of loyal JC fans from before their big upgrade from the way people interacted like old friends. This has been one of the best bars/lounges I have been too in SF and I would definitely recommend it.
author: Monlia W.

description:
We came here last weekend. my friends and i weren't happy with XYZ and Eve so we left and wanted to find another. We were planning to go to Dada but we passed by John Colins, their music made us forget our original plan.

We went in, no cover, they had a small dancing floor and we just dance the last 30 minutes before they closed. The crowd was pretty mix, ages from 25s to early 30s. This definitely made our night a lot better. I'd like to go back there again and see
author: Viola C.

description: Great service, really cool staff, and the craft drinks are unique takes on your favorite classics. Negative reviewers forget that it's a bar... And bars get busy sometimes. Be patient if its a full house and take in the atmosphere.
author: Brian D.

description: The people are amazing! Bartender was attentive to all people, quick and easy service. The music (hip hop) is great but it was quite smaller than I expected. I love a good service -and I definitely got it here!
author: Kristelle S.

description:
I thought this place would be much more douchey than it was. Drinks were expensive but I was smashed after only 4 - what is IN those mojitos???

Music was a little loud but it was really spot on. I don't go to a bar and hear band of horses played very much but it really fit the atmosphere - a little chill but not boring.

Mexican food right out front was much appreciated. 2 mins from montgomery bart station doesn't hurt. 

I will be a repeat offender.
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
This seems obvious to me but some bars just don't seem to get it. People go to bars to drink and talk, people go to nightclubs to listen to music and dance. 

There is no reason for loud music in a bar. The music should be a background that encourages conversation. This bar has speakers in every corner so there's no escaping what the DJ feels like inflicting on you. While I was there I had to put up with scrotum shaking repetitive Bass noises, some kind of government sonic torture experiment I figure, which segued into the soundtrack of Disney's jungle ride all the time yelling into my friends ears to be heard.

On Mondays they have happy hour prices all night so at least I was getting a good deal but their beer selection is sad.
author: Manny F.

description:
John Colins is my go-to Happy Hour bar. I feel like it's kind of a Financial District institution and it's easy to see why. The bartenders are friendly and attentive, the HH drink specials are great, and even though the space is small, most is made of the space and one can usually find seating before 6:30 pm. The crowd is generally comprised of the after-work crowd, but I haven't observed any "see and be seen" type of attitudes that one gets at some other after-work spots - it's mostly people kicking back with a drink or two before heading home.

I know that the bar is moving it's location at the end of the month and I hope it doesn't lose it's charm in the move. However, with such a great staff, I'm sure it will be a seamless transition.
author: Randi W.

description:
Ugh.

We wandered here searching for a place to get drinks and shake our booties after closing out at Thirsty Bear. The crowd was utterly bizarre, and the DJ was HORRIBLE. He wouldn't take requests, and he didn't play music for dancing. On our way out, I told the bouncer that the DJ was useless, and he looked apathetic. Yeah....

They could do better.
author: Sarah T.

description:
Work's out, the short hand hit 5...time to see John and he's pretty cool

Awesome that we stopped by this bar at an alley on our way to another party and that it put me on secretive mode like finding the hidden market of alcohol sold during the prohibition era. It's a far fetched imagination but I won't have to worry about any cops tailing me...

In any manner, if you're looking for a place to ultimately unwind with your co-workers then John Collins can grant just that...it's cool for cats, ya know? Everybody seemed comfortable...the hipster & yuppie mixed crowd holding their glasses & discussing the late afternoon away as if they're wearing jeans & sneakers behind those work suits or pumps.

Music was great...electronic, deep house...sorta like thievery corp meets Tiesto. They go well with a dirty martini!
author: Charmian D.

description:
Just get dressed up and walk right into the door. This is the place for spontaneous folks who don't like RSVPing ahead of time.  That's right, they have no cover charges!  And don't worry, the drinks were moderately priced yet strong.  

Pretty classy (not too fancy) decor with decent dance music. The place is big enough to comfortably hold our group of ~40 people plus other people that night.   Not too big nor small dance floor that was well ventilated (ok...maybe that also depends on the crowd density).  I'd go back here again.  One thing thing though...they only have 3 unisex bathrooms, so the wait can be a bit painful.
author: Numrin T.

description:
