Came over here on a saturday night and got lost going here, but granted its cuz i was ball parking it on the map and minna is not the easiest street to find at night.

it was full  at 10 and pretty sure packed by like 11:30ish, when i left at 12:45 there was a pretty decent line.  

Its a pretty nice joint clean, friendly, but it is overall a narrow place and the bar crowd kinda greats a wall between the two sections of the place.

Very enjoyable, good drinks,good music, even had a projector playing a kung fu movie....a fun lil place, right off of union square
author: Justin N.

description:
NEWS FLASH: I'VE DISCOVERED THE SECRET HIDEOUT OF THE HOTTEST GUYS IN THE BAY.

I came here to celebrate my friend's 26th birthday, and I only ordered one drink because I wanted to stay sober enough to people watch (EVERYONE starts looking good after I drink too much, and I wanted to distinguish fact from fiction). 

They have a DJ booth upstairs that overlooks the entire lower level, which consists of a bar and a make-shift dance floor. The walls are lined with comfy booths and tables to lounge at (perfect for me, because I was wearing 4" stiletto heels and my lazy ass didn't feel like standing the whole night). 

My lemon drop was rimmed with sugar AND salt, which I thought was strange, and could feel my cholesterol levels going up with every sip. I only drank half, before I was distracted by a boy, who later finished my drink and told me it still tasted good warm. 

Fast forward to the morning after, and I have a massive headache and extreme nausea. 

How the EFF do you get a hangover from half a drink?!
author: Chang L.

description: Nice lively scene with a killer bar selection and cool bartenders. Not cheap but not pricey just your sf standard price. The dance floor is moderate, but a very cool bar to venture to in SoMa
author: Devin S.

description: I've always like John Collins but seem to make it over there very often.  Drinks are always good and I vaguely remember the seating was comfortable.  I'm usually pretty trashed by the time we make it there so I don't quite remember.  Maybe that is why I don't frequent this place very often.
author: Suz L.

description: I was invited to come for happy hour with a co-worker. The crowd was pretty mixed, but it wasn't my cup of tea. Everyone seemed to be huddled in the back with a few people scattered in the front and upstairs. The drinks were good and after a few drinks the crowd seemed to be much more interesting. If I have to hang out here with beer goggles it's probably not a good thing.
author: Adelina W.

description:
Super cozy little bar hidden down the alley, steps from 111 Minna. 

We came here for some post-dinner drinks on a Tuesday/Wednesday night. Upon entering, we were greeted with a small stage to the right and a [mediocre] band. There were only 4 people at the bar; the drinks were good and the people were friendly. 

Live music, good people, cute drinks in mason jars. What more could you ask for from your neighborhood bar?
author: Sue Y.

description: I'm not a fan of this place at all so it makes me sad that this spot is the go to for Happy Hours. The wine just isn't very good, the music is always insanely loud, it's always crowded, so you can't hear anyone -- even if you're standing RIGHT IN FRONT OF THEM. Bleh, there are other bars that have a better selection and a better atmosphere.
author: Shauna S.

description:
Wow...

Went here with a couple of friends this weekend and boy was I impressed!!!  I always here my friends talking about how great this place is and I never really pay them any attention because I normally don't party in SF.  Strictly OAK girl :)

To my surprise, I was shocked.  

I loved the ambiance of this place.  It was a total shocker if you check it out from the outside.  The place was packed as if this was the spot that I surely didn't know about.

The house DJ was great.  Played an array of music that was awesome.

I got a chance to meet John and his wife and that was cool :)

What I loved most about this place:
The screen where you get to watch clips of an old movie playing
The fact that the door is literally like a curtain...soooo cool
And last but not least like normal lounge settings this place didn't have too many tables and chairs around.  So if you wanted to shake a tail feather...which I'm known to do, you have plenty of room ;)
author: Sandra S.

description:
So I really do like this bar. No cover charge, no dress code, always a seat at the bar, great chill place to hang out at. The only reason I'm giving it 4 stars rather than 5 is because some of the other customers are hella sketchy! 

A week ago I was there and some real creepos wouldn't get the hint to leave us alone, but since it was bar close the bartender let us chill after hours so we didn't get followed home. 

I've gone back since then and I will continue to go back! I really feel that its the bartenders that make this place so enjoyable. They're always really friendly and I think it just creates a welcoming atmosphere. Plus there's never a line for the bathroom, never real crowded, and we always find a seat at the bar!
author: Megan L.

description: Happy hour menu is pretty good, the bar area is spacey.  I like how they provide pretzels and goldfish.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Love JC. 

this has definitely been my go to spot when i just want to grab a couple of drinks. everyone's super chill and it doesn't matter where you're coming from - it'll be a good time at john colins. 

whether it's celebrating a birthday or catching the game, i'm a fan of the vibe. djs play good music you can either get up and dance to. or just grab a couple seats and have your own thing going on. 

my only gripe is when it's crazy packed on the weekends. but wouldn't you expect that anyways? 

you'll probably find me here fridays after off the grid. ha!
author: Maria B.

description:
Probably one of the better spots in San Francisco. I like John Colins because you just never know what to expect in there. But that's a part of the fun. I've seen many clubs and bars that attract a certain crowd. John Colins doesn't have a type. Every person from the grad student to the hip hop heads to the older mid-life crisis douchebag comes here. The females range between conservative 30 something females who gather once a month to the hot girls who dress in the tiny skirts and stilettos, and even extremely casually dressed girls who just want to dance. Even the ethnic backgrounds are quite the mix. 

The DJs are somewhat random. Some nights you'll have a ton of House music and other nights there will be a mix of Hip Hop, Top 40 and even a bit of Reggae thrown in here and there. 

Before you get into the club, the laid back guy with the ponytail is usually checking IDs and letting people. He always seems pretty cool and seems to enjoy his job. Always makes it a more easygoing experience getting into any place. As you look forward to your left before getting in you'll also notice a Korean Taco truck. So if you're sorta hungry, you can grab a small bite for about 2 bucks a taco. It's actually pretty tasty. Plus you can get a cheaper soda than what the bar charges.

Once you get in, the dance floor is to your immediate right and some seating to your immediate left. The bar goes from one end to the other and it doesn't curve around to any other sides. The bar is almost always full and you have to kinda push your way in and say "Excuse me" because sometimes it seems as if people are determined to stand or sit at the bar area for the entire evening. The drinks are not real stiff, but they're decent. Once you get to the bar area, and you turn around to look up, there's always some movie playing above your head. The films they decide to choose are random as well.

There is no cover to get in, which I love. There's been times where I dropped in early, then I left, and came back again without a problem. The crowd is super laid back and pretty friendly. The mix of people always make it somewhat interesting. The dance floor is small, so get on it early if you want to make a spot for you and your friends. 

The place never gets super exciting, so if you're looking for an extremely upbeat vibe, look elsewhere. If you're looking to have a few drinks and to dance a bit, this might be a nice little fit for your taste.

Oh, 20 dollar minimum on cards. I would just open a tab and buy a few, then close it out. The drinks are not cheap, so that 20 dollars can get used up within a single round with enough people. Otherwise cash is your only option.
author: Prince B.

description:
What do you do when you've had a really shitty week???  Kill your problems with alcohol of course!  My friends were going to John Colins and told me to come out to unwind.  I had just enough time before my client dinner, so I stopped by for a drink.

I walked in at 5:15, and it was pretty much a sausage fest.  There weren't that many people there yet, but it was all guys...too bad none were cute.  The place itself is pretty nice.  There's lots of seating and the drinks are pretty cheap.  My Hangar & Tonic was about $7 and beers were $3.  The music was good, but a tad bit loud....I kept saying..."WHAT??? HUUUH??"  

All in all, it was a nice little bar to grab some drinks after work.  Just don't expect to have a deep, meaningful conversation with the music blaring in the background.
author: Patra I.

description:
The John Colins:
A hefty pour of white bro dudes
A splash of jiggly chicks in glittery BCBG dresses
A crowded bar
A decent place to sit in the back if you get here early
A small dance floor playing 90's jams that you dont really want to dance to
And a sprinkling of some cool art on the wall...
The end result  an OK place to hang out in SOMA that is off the beaten track and is less annoying than most other bars in the area.
author: M K.

description:
When it's too cold or cloudy to have apps and pops on Zebulon's patio, I hunker into John Colins for a cozier experience. 

I try to sneak out before the DJ pumps the dBs louder than my fragile ears can handle, but there's usually ample time for a few rounds with some pals before dinner or something.
author: Lorna M.

description:
Did I mention the bartenders are nice eye candy, and that they serve their shots in these boot shaped shot glasses?  

And when I spill a tray full of shots on myself, the bartender so kindly remakes them for me?
author: Denise B.

description: Nice place. I cam here on a Thursday after work with a friend for drink. I biked in so I was under-dressed but nobody gave me any bad looks. The people were really cool and the bartender gave us a taster of the punch, which was good. The music was fun and loud. I missed the happy hour by over an hour so I wasn't drunk enough for the dancing when it started but it looked like a lot of fun.
author: Stephen S.

description:
Great place to add to your list of SOMA bars. It's close to BART too, which makes it convenient for non-SFers. 

The drinks, $6-10, are VERY strong. 

Small dance floor towards the front, where the DJ is. Lounging space towards the back.
author: Saori E.

description:
I went for a meeting in Moscone center. This place is very good very close for sneaking out of the meeting :P.
Very classy, very nice decor :)
Price is reasonable :D
author: P O.

description: Had an invitation for lunch at a local place during the week and it turned out to be here.  I have no idea about this part of town, but the meeting went well.  People like me have a hard time figuring out sometimes if these places are 'Irish' or 'Scottish' in character, or even 'Scotch - Irish.'  Fine.
author: Thomas H S.

description: Stumbled over to John Collins from eve, and it was crackin! Good music, good vibes, had a good time!
author: Tiff C.

description:
John Collins is a cool space. It's like walking into a Ruehl clothing store (leather sofas, dim lighting, oversized oil paintings of bulldogs) without the nauseating signature scent being continuously pumped into the air, bombarding your nostrils and seeping into your pores. 

What John Colins does have that Ruehl does not are vaulted ceilings, a full bar, and a DJ room one level up that is visible from the entrance. The music last weekend was mostly hip hop, the vibe was laid back, and the crowd was young and lively. Street parking was relatively easy to find. Lots are available within a block's walk for $8/night if you're too lazy to circle the neighborhood.
author: Elaine T.

description:
The door guy  hassled me for using a "fake id" MOTHER F'ER I am almost 30! asshole! and then when we got in, it was freaking SLOW! no one was in there! pass... 

but my friend told me this was a great place for happy hour, and she said it might change my mind when I come back, and that the nightlife at jc isn't cool.. so maybe I will give it another go.
author: Nina M.

description:
Been here once and had a wonderful time.It's Cute and cozy here. Im a fan!

Will definitely return
author: linda L.

description:
I go here every 2nd Thursday of the month for King Kooba and the Trout. The music is amazing, the atmosphere feels like Brooklyn or a Manhattan meat packing district hideaway. The high brick walls antiquify the atmosphere and the skylight windows give you views of SF's new high rises are an awesome contrast. They usually play surf movies on the wall above the door to add to atmosphere. I just dig on the music and vibe of the place, people are pretty nice, tend to get a bit drunk towards the end so you end up with some pretty crazy, drama conversations but most of the time it's just chill. 

Drinks are standard, nothing special or standout and don't drink the wine it taste like vinegar. I nearly choked on their 2 buck chuck Merlot. Please a warning would have been nice. I would stay with the staples or vodka tonic or something clean and easy to fix. Beer selection is good too and prices are not through the roof. All in all I just come for the music on 2nd Thursdays. King Kooba and the Trout rock it like you would never even imagine with old school dance hall music that has a definite British bend to it.
author: Teisha F.

description:
I visited their new location the other day and I can say it's a big change (but a good one).  The previous location was very cozy and initmate - but sometimes it got too crowded that you couldn't move.  The new location - still tucked away in a small alley, maintains its intimate atmosphere, but is slightly more spacious.  I did go on Tuesday night so our group had a lot more space to move around.  It's a good place to just hang out and chill with good company.  The overall crowd was pretty chill and relaxed -just how I like it.  

Just one note, I'm a fan of mojitos...but my cousin bought me a mojito and it tasted like medicine that I couldn't finish it - but there are so many other specialties you can order that are much better.
author: Michelle F.

description:
Love this place. I came here for Happy Hour last night and instantly loved the exposed brick and leather bench seating. I got up to the bar and ordered a Kettle One gimlet on the rocks and got excited when I saw the juicer come out. I love it when they're made with fresh lime juice!!!! The cocktail was perfect and not expensive. I had that and I ordered a vodka tonic and a vodka Red Bull for my friends and it was $17! can't beat that. 

Finding a seat was more challenging but after a while we squeezed around a small table with seats. The place gets pretty crowded but it's not overwhelming. The vibe was very chill, the music was good and not too loud where you couldn't have a conversation. While there isn't that much seating, there is an open floor plan so it's easy enough to move around.
author: Lindsay A.

description:
Went here on a Saturday night as a pre-party location. Got there early and they weren't open yet  (they opened at 9pm). In the dark it was kind of hard to see where the place was. They were nice and let us wait inside as opposed to freezing outside. The inside was very nicely decorated and great atmosphere. Lots of room to mill around with some seating towards the back. 

After the place filled up a bit, both times that I ordered a drink I had another bartender come up and ask me if I was being helped, which I thought was pretty nifty since most of the time I am lucky to get any orders in. 

They had a $5 tequila shot or margarita combo which a couple of us thought was pretty good deal and very tasty. Freshly squeezed juice and all. 

The projector playing movies was also pretty fun to watch. 

Would definetely go back again!
author: Ethan H.

description:
It's a small trendy spot located in a quaint little alley --- close to great restaurants, such as Anchor and Hope, Osha Thai, and Zebulon. Also walking distance from many nightclubs such as Temple and Harlot. 

I've been here after work and also during the later hours. Personally, I think John Collins is at best a good happy hour experience. The crowd is mixed and it's definitely a great atmosphere. The music bumpin' is usually my flavor -- r&b and hiphop. HAppy hour prices bring a smile to my face......it's also conveniently located about 2 blocks from Bart. 

Downside: It's small...so expect bumper to bumper, long bathroomm lines, and no dancing...
author: Kat M.

description:
Good music, good service, and a cool space with exposed brick. It was pretty crowded when I went here with a few friends, partially due to a girl's birthday party in the back corner.

Not a whole lot of seating, and there's a smallish dance floor in the back.
author: Kenny J.

description:
Went there on a random wed for happy hour. the drinks were good and the service was ok.

one complaint about the bar area is that the bar counter top has a curved edge. so when you spill something it will roll DOWN the counter top and drip onto your legs!. that's like the worst bar top design ever! it's like the more you drink,  the more wet you could possibly get. and i do not mean that in a nasty way...haha

i would go there again but i would find a table next time.
author: Irene L.

description:
I really like the new location.

More room and more seats!! High ceilings. Exposed brick walls. Contemporary and relaxing vibe. Definitely an upgrade from the old location. There is also a small VIP room that is perfect for a small group. I was lucky enough to use it. I reserved it for my group. We had our own TV to watch some March Madness games! Yeah!

This is a great place to meet up with friends for happy hour. Drinks are stiff but not much of a happy hour special. All drinks are only $1 off. Woohoo.... 

Well, at least you get complementary bar pretzels and goldfish crackers.
author: Molly T.

description:
This place is legit. 

I come here after work every once in a while to get some drinks and get ready for the weekend. They have good drink specials and an excellent selection of booze. Lots of good rums, tequilas whiskeys and other spirits. They have good music and it's played at a perfect level. I hate places where I can't hear the person next to me.

This joint is pretty small and gets retarded busy, especially on Fridays after work. So get here early to get a seat or be prepared to stand and get bumped into.
author: Jeff P.

description:
Decor is def. nice.  The bartenders know what they are doing which is a plus.  There is always standing room, if not seats. But the one star I took away was the bathroom does not lock!! WTH! WTH!!!

I just have a fear of people walking in when I'm peeing, so that was a pretty awful experience as I'm sitting there and you know that when you drink you got a lot more liquid coming out.. so it was pretty bad.
author: AhLin C.

description:
A cool but not too pretentious atmosphere... perfect place for a chill night with some drinks and some dancing. I've come here a few times and each time I had a good time! It can get a little claustrophobic at times especially the hallway thing with the bar, but overall it's better to have more people there than none at all, right? There is a line starting a little after 11 that can be a little annoying, but there isn't cover after all.
I like the dance floor - the DJ plays lots of top 40 stuff that is fun and easy to dance to =) 
A word about the bar: It has some 'artistic' nature to it in that the edge is a tapering end where if you so happen to place a glass on it, it will slide off and spill onto your lap. I'm not gonna lie, this happened to me and the drink fell in @betty w.'s lap. OOPS! =x 
They usually have some special drinks for the night. When i went they had $4 harlem shots, and $5 1800 tequila shots. yay! 
I'll def. be back. (if you think roe a few blocks down is whack ... which, lets face it, it is... then make your way over here and your night will be lot better) OH! and they had the korean taco truck outside that was a very nice drunken surprise. =D
author: Tim B.

description: Vodka gimlet with lime was great-fresh, crisp and strong but not too strong. Wasnt here long, just had a few drinks with a friend but I'd come back if I'm in the area again
author: Beini S.

description:
The ambulances can be so mixed here on a Wed HH vs Fri HH. Friday's are much more happening at John Colin's but they have $2 off cocktails and $1 off beer for HH 5-7pm. $14 for two drinks.

They have some special Giants Specials and they play the game on the projector. 

This place is pretty central in soma so it is easy to meet up with friends who work North and South of John Colin's. 

I wish they had food though?!
author: Jeanne C.

description: So crowded for Friday happy hour, but that's a good sign for a good bar! They even serve pretzels/goldfish snacks (but you have to ask the bartender for some). I just wish this place had some kind of seats so that you didnt have to stand up the whole time, and that it wasn't so...dark.
author: Melody L.

description:
Blah! I miss the old location.

Now it feels like a club rather than an after work  watering hole.

Although this place is larger and nicer, I think thats all it has going for it.  The bouncers are rude, its stuffy, pricier drinks (no doubt to recoup cost for new place), and a dance floor??? *sigh*

I'll give this place more time to get their act together.
author: Sun T.

description:
How to be responsible:

1.) Next morning: pleasepleasepleasepleaseplease! *opens wallet and finds credit card* YES!
2.) Going to Mel's drunk and still ordering a vegetarian sandwich. 
3.) Making it home safely... I think.

"Have a plan. Stick to it."
-Layer Cake


How to be irresponsible:

1.) Turning on the stove and furnace, and falling asleep. (So warm.)
2.) Pan-frying a pancake all night. (I'll probably still eat it...)


How to save your own ass:

1.) Leaving the bathroom fan on.

"Have a fan. Click to it."
-Keane L.

My requirements for a five-star bar are very simple:
1.) Accept credit.
2.) Get a drink in my hand. Fast.
3.) Lots of cool people.
4.) Breathing room.
5.) Prospect of sex.

Were they fulfilled? Observe:

1.) Including AMEX.
2.) Unfortunately.
3.) Best DYL in awhile.
4.) I could even wear my corset.
5.) I said "prospect," without definition of timeframe... so, still good!

PS: The bartender's name is Leilani and she was born in Hawaii. Being from Hawaii myself, I think that's pretty cool.

PPS: There were FOUR people from my high school last night. Amazing!

~~~~~~~~~~~~

Dedication: Fare thee well, Rye G. It was nice hanging with you one last time.
author: Keane L.

description:
John Colins is That Guy.  

That guy who gets you comped at Rooftops, Undergrounds, Sunset / Sunrise, The After After, The Sold Outs.  NOT because he lays down the $ (because let's face it he has no $).  But because he's John Colins.

John Colins is that guy whose mom showed up naked (laughing) in a tub with 2 other ladies in an Andy Warhol short; modeled for Salvador Dali; and whose interracial wedding in Martha's Vineyard inspired an Oprah movie of the week starring Hallie Berry.

John Colins is that guy descended from Harlem Renaissance poets and writers who went west to make movies.  And on the way stopped to say "hey" at an Ivy League, Billie Mo, Sony and is now writing a documentary on Fannie Lou Hamer.

John Colins is that guy, lanky, sure, observing, who alludes to Karl Marx as easy as he burns you sounds, sounds and more sounds you have never heard before; and offers you DJ Shadow passes, "Whenever."  Well, because, he does something. Like, band merchandising, or something.

John Colins is that guy you want to see again and again. Because you feel like his coolness will rub off on you. 

And even when it doesn't.  John Colins will make you an immaculate Effen Black Cherry Vodka and Club Soda for $7.
author: Natasha S.

description:
Cozy, modern, fun place in SOMA. Great for Happy Hours. Not sure if the drinks are pricy since i didn't have to pay for them...
Was here on a Thursday evening, so the crowds were not too crazy and there was plenty of room to hang out. The seating area would do well with more tables/ table-space though...we were awkwardly holding our drinks for a while...
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
What is it with me and bathrooms?

I must have been a temperamental toilet in a past life or something, because I have the worst luck with bathrooms in this one!

So last night, we headed over to John Collins for a little after work libationage. I have my new LA girl in town so we had to show her around and since JC is so close to work, why not.

Upon entering, I thought we had accidentally entered Anchor and Hope. Very similar design with the high ceiling and the exposed brick, but I guess when you share the same building, tis bound to happen. After saddling up to the bar, we started ordering drinks. I was super tired and needed a second wind so i opted for the Espresso martini. The mantender said it actually had caffeine in the vodka (sweet!!!) and whether that was true or not, the drink definitely put a kick back into my step.

From there we proceeded to drink a few more martinis and low and behold, it was time to break the seal. Yep, a girl can only go so long without a ladies room stop ;) And so I headed to said ladies room and wouldn't you know, it was occupied. Damn! But what's this, the men's room is open, hmmmmmm.

Eh, falk it, why not. And so I headed in and locked the door. From there, I began my business and what happens next? Oh, ya know, the friggin door opens and there stands a man looking for his room. 

"Shit, shit shit!!" was what I exclaimed and quickly kicked the door shut. Oh my god! How embarrassing and of course he was cute. Why wouldn't he be? That is just my luck. And so I washed my hands and made sure the bright red mortified glow was still on my cheeks and exited the bathroom. He was trying to contain his laughter and when I looked at him, he looked at me and we both burst into laughter. 

Ahhh, I love life.
author: Stephy S.

description:
FUN crowd!!!!!!!!

I loooooove the decor, especially the huge painting of a pit bull on the wall.  I personally love pit bulls (the Vallejo in me) so I'm drawn to that painting.  The exposed brick, leather bench seating, and loud afro beat/electronica music.  If you want a quieter setting, go upstairs. 

Had my birthday happy hour here and my friends nabbed a table and chairs downstairs.  We were drunk, loud, and silly, and the bartenders stayed funny and nice.  Lots of collared shirt wearing guys with spiky hair resembling the Marina without the attitude.  No cover, no dress code, mature and fun crowd.

Only problem is the that it's hidden in an alley so it might be a difficult to find the first time.
author: Nezza F.

description:
I am starting with the good and leading up to the bad here folks, so pay attention.

The first part of this review is expressly for the doorman (who prefers to be called "the host"....so check it, and call the man the host!).

He will make you go to the corner to smoke if the neighbors call his cell phone and ask him to keep it down. Yes, that's right, the neighbors have his cell phone #, he gave it to them, so that they can call him, so that he can make sure they actually get some peace and quiet in their homes, and so this establishment doesn't get shut down from the noise complaints!!! 

He will also tell you to get out of the road. The man is not trying to argue with you drunk people, he is trying to keep your asses alive....I don't know if you have noticed, but the people in this city drive CRAZY. 

He also requires you to pick up your cigarette butts and dispose of them properly instead of throwing them in the gutter in front of the bar (good man). 

Listen to the man, he is wise. I heard a bit of smack talking from a few drunk yelpers about his rules. Shut your mouths, he is trying to help! A big 5 stars for "The Host".

The bartenders were completely efficient despite the large crowd. They noticed me looking thirsty in the crowd several times and got me my drinks quickly.

They were showing surf videos when I first arrived, and I am kind of a surf video junkie. I can watch them for hours....too damn bad that the surf videos turned into Michael Jackson videos. Why????

Bad, bad, bad on the bathroom situation..big lines all night long....redesign and add a few stalls.....oh, and get doors that lock! I don't need a huge line of people seeing something I generally reserve for that special person in my life.

It was while I was in that bathroom line, killing time by people watching, that I realized that if you took the yelpers out of the bar the clientele would be a mix of Marina and Walnut Creek.  I am going with a theory that this only happens on the weekends, saving this place from a 2 star rating, because, dammit, I really want to rate it higher for the people who work here.
author: Drue C.

description:
What is it with everyone who sees a Blackman sitting or standing by the BAR entrance, they assume DOORMAN?  Well, I had a lot of fun "acting" as Mr. Doorman...  I didn't actually check anyone's ID, however I did ask, they'd show, and then I'm like "no no no jk... I'm not the doorman."  ;0)  
Will the real doorman please stand up, please stand up?  Oh he did and damn he's big.  A brotha that size you'd think he'd be something like a meathead.  Nope!  He was extremely polite, friendly, and in control of his Motha F*ckin Sh*t.  I mean if he asked you to jump you'd respond, "How Hi Sir?"  Oh and why look at him crazy when he tells you to stay out the street?  "Keep the God damn yuppies out the street."  Would hate to see someone get hit for being dumb.

Bathrooms:  well I think I used the women's once because there was a line for the men's.  That statement speaks for itself

Bartender: He had a gray SF Niners cap, dude took good care of me ($10 DJC? Yes siiirrr).

Happy Hour: Shhhiittt, never again.  I think instead of saying, "excuse me, excuse me" I should have said, "Move B**** get out the way."

After Happy Hour: Yes, I will come back... the mood and the crowd seems to completely change... plus you have room to move around, and dance if you want to ;0)

See you after 9pm.
author: Jamal G.

description:
Today, after work, I discovered a new favorite bar.  I loved the laid back feel of this place.  The acid jazz reminded me of back home..the only thing missing was "trailer park night" where you could get anything dipped in batter.

Free tequila from the girl at the end of the bar?  I'll drink to that.  

Several spots to comfortably sit.  Great to strike up a conversation or strategically pose and look fierce, a la Tyra B.
author: Janney B.

description:
I was late for the happy hour and got there around 9:40pm.  It was still very crowded so I couldn't get a drink.

The dude bartender is HOT.  HOT.  The little girl bartender is HOT too... well I thought her haircut was totally cute.  But... dude bartender was definitely HOT... I couldn't even make eye contact with him, he was THAT sizzling.

Anywayz.  They had a DJ booth upstairs with another room where people can chill.. I didn't go there coz it was crowded.

They have a projector that blasted films on the wall above the entrance.  THey were showing Thriller and Breakin'.  Awesome.  

The pineapple malibu that cute bartender lady made for me was in a taller glass, didn't have too much ice in it, and it was well made!  They do a $15 minimum for credit card tabs.

It settled down a bit after 11pm, so there was room to dance.  Gabriel, Marie, Drue, Karen K, Carla sometimes, and I were trying to get our groove thang going to the nice mix of hip hop hits that the DJ played.

No random lapdances given, y'all... I only had ONE drink!  

Taking a cue from Ed M...I'm being goodED to myself too!
author: Grace M.

description:
A loungey bar where you can actually chat without yelling?! Does a such a place exist? Yes! Great cozy space! I love the brick walls, the happy hour $3 well drink and $1 off any other drink deals, and the obscure location.  

Will definitely be back and spread the word about this place...or not. :o)
author: Aim E.

description:
I like this bar.  The bartenders were cool, drinks affordable ($5 for a jack and coke at happy hour is a pretty good deal in my book) and a huge turnout of Yelpers for DYL.  I even talked to some girls and didn't come across as a total creep-hooray, me!
-1 star for the bathroom situation...boo long lines to pee standing up.
author: phil h.

description:
Whenever I visit John Colins I feel like a lemming.  You know, those small furry animals who, according to urban legend and at least one Far Side cartoon, like to follow each other around so much they end up falling off cliffs together.  Well, the happy hour crowd at John Colins reminds me of one of those hordes of unintentionally suicidal mammals --- so many people follow each other into this small space that eventually you become sure that you're going to be crushed and die.  

Hey, whether you fall off the cliff or get smushed against the bar, the squishy results are the same, right?

As Gabriel T has mentioned, the lemmings leave around 9pm and the bar becomes a more comfortable space full of consciously ironic kitsch and bartenders with pleasant dispositions.  It's not a place I volunteer as an option, but it is a place I will go to if asked...but not at happy hour again.
author: Suzanne B.

description:
I've only been here on Fridays and Saturdays to go out late night, not for happy hour. As with all my bar/lounge/club reviews, I'll provide only the pertinent information:

Dress code: none really. Collared shirt or nice t-shirt will be fine. Chucks are fine too. No dress shoes needed.

Cover: there is none. HOWEVER, if you're with a bunch of dudes and the line is long, you're better off giving the bouncer a couple bucks (maybe $5 each) to waltz right in. It's probably worth it. And if you can't afford $5, you probably won't end up getting lucky anyway.

Drinks: Really reasonable prices. Example - Bought 4 shots of Stoli for about $28. That should give you a decent idea. Since there's only one bar, it will take FOREVER to get a drink. Not saying the bartenders suck, but it does piss us off.

Crowd: At least 50% Asian, rest is mixed. A lot of birthday crowds. Pretty good looking people most of the time. Hey, that's what's important at bars right?

Dance: there's a pretty decent area with a DJ for dancing. He usually plays top 40s so the girls would appreciate that.

I gave this place 4 stars because it's a pretty legit "default" place to go. There'll always be a decent looking crowd, a good handful of people and cheap drinks/good music.
author: Tery L.

description:
I'm willing to forget that the bartender took a long ass time and forgot my drink order the first time. Here's why:

The space is comfortable and nicely decorated. Check out the Sam Flores painting by the door and the portraits of pit bulls. There's a fair amount of seating and a lot of standing room. It gets crowded early on but it's the politest bunch of yuppies you'll ever meet.

I was sure I was the only person in SF who owned and like Terje Rypdal's self titled album, but apparently the DJ here is into it too.

And their electricity meter is right out in the open, giving you some insight into the bar's energy consumption. It was actually less than I expected. Thanks for doing your part, John Colins!
author: matthew r.

description: Great place to come in and have a stress relief drink after work. Great people to mingle with and very chill atmosphere
author: Jimmy H.

description:
Here's what I have to say about John Colins:
-Crowded
-Loud
-Expensive

Not my first choice for a happy hour; but, I can see how this place might gain another star and continued patronage from me on a slower weeknight... yet it is in SoMa, which makes this bar a pain in the ass to get to and from for me.

Meh.
Didn't suck, wasn't great.  I may go back.
author: Kate R.

description:
Nice new place, same great people, same great drinks!

I definitely like the new place John Colins is in now. It definitely looks cleaner, bigger, and has the great ambiance to forget all of your worries. 

The bartenders are still nice as hell and the owner hooked me up with a few drinks after talking to him for a bit. The new t-shirts are bomb too and I love the snacks that are self-serve to sober you up!
author: Langdon N.

description:
This place was cool, I really liked the brick walls and random paintings on the wall...the painting of the pit bull was my favorite..

It was fun to watch Scarface up on the wall!

Drinks were stiff, crowd was 'lax...

The music could have been better though....

Nice place to chill and hang out with friends..
author: Jade B.

description:
I think I discovered the secret to having a GREAT happy hour:

On any given Tuesday, bring a hot friend and a game of SET, and then give monosyllabic answers to any strange male that comes within a 3 foot radius [anyone outside of that radius can be simply ignored on account of ambient noise that makes it incredibly difficult to hear stupid questions].

EXAMPLE: [lay out SET on a table, and occupy a whole corner of the bar/lounge with your game/bags/etc. Play SET. Don't forget your drinks]
Random guy: What are you playing?
You: [silence on account of 'ambient noise']
RG [5 min later]: What are you playing?
You: [silence on account of aforementioned 'noise']
RG [5 more min later]: What are you girls playing?
You: SET
RG: What is that?
Your hot friend: A game.

Works like a charm. :)
author: Liza P.

description:
Effen black cherry - need I say more?  This is a great spot that attracts a hip urban crowd.  It reminds me of a few lounges I used to frequent while living in Tribeca.  I like the music and ambience and it's proven to be a great spot to take dates.   

One must ask themselves when going here, WWJC do?  I think the answer is have another drink and take it all in.
author: John M.

description:
Disclaimer: This review does not cover Friday nights or any sort of food!  

Ok admittedly I went there for happy hour on a Tuesday.  Drinks well priced, not too crowded and a pleasant crowd there on an otherwise slow night in the city.  I like it!
author: Dean F.

description:
Is it just me, or are there a lot of sexy black men at this bar?  I dropped in here randomly last Friday with a girlfriend after a drink or 7 at Yoshis and was trilled to find a hottie selection of hipster black men swigging choice cocktails and wearing cute hats.  WTF?  It was heaven. 

The beats were pretty good, but unsure that I would say that if I hadn't already been inebriated, yes I did dance to "What Have You Done For me Lately" but it was with one of the hot, hatted black men so I didn't give a shit.  My champagne cocktail was pretty nasty but I hate those drinks anyway and have no idea why I ordered it.  

This bar is officially good times.
author: Claire C.

description:
While I like the new JC, I miss the former one... there, I said it. 

I went there on Thurs for HH and it was SO LOUD, I remember walking by the bathroom and laughing because the floors and doors were shaking. Even my hair was vibrating! Maybe just bring it down 2 notches so we don't have to scream quite as much, I was hoarse by the end of the night. 

Other than that the crowd is still the same, which I like. Mostly after work people out for happy hour to commiserate over drinks. And friendly (and super cute!) bartenders who enjoy making good drinks so I keep coming back for more.
author: Nenette Y.

description:
A great stop in for a refreshing cocktail... 

The atmosphere is lively and all the bartenders are friendly. There is a great assortment of cocktail remedies waiting to be ordered... 

Try the spicy shot. It'll be sure to wake you up or take you right out of your seat.
author: Dee C.

description: No shorts allowed for boys, but the bouncer will let you slide if 20 of your friends run out to greet you upon arrival.
author: Jane N.

description:
I know John and I know Colin --hence the cool bar name John Collins...clever eh? 

Great spot for happy hour or anytime -- brick walls with big artwork and  a movie is playing right over the doorway when you walk in. Lighting makes for some attractive people during the workweek grabbing a drink before heading home.  

Reasonably priced drinks that are fairly stiff and they have a good selection of alcohol.  If you go to the Qool party this is a great spot to start up. 

One of my favorite bars in SF..
author: Morgan H.

description: Hung out here with 2 other couples and we had a great time. Drinks were great and so was the music. LOVED the pit bull art! Is it for sale?
author: N H.

description:
When I went here, I was pretty much sardined 90% of the time. The place gets packed like CRAZY. I'm not sure if this happens every weekend, but I've been to better bars. However, despite the overcrowding issue, the folks are nice and very chill. The drinks are relatively cheap and that's what counts, right? 

People call it a bar but it's more like a hybrid bar/club considering it's mini dance floor and sleek lounges. If you don't mind the club-like atmosphere in a bar setting, this place is pretty good.
author: Clifford P.

description:
This bar used to be one of my favorite spots in SF -- under the radar, good crowd, great drinks; size is just about right, decor and mood are perfect. The staff is nice and efficient.

Unfortunately, the last part is where it all went wrong. I'm sure the bartenders are still great, but the bouncer managed to, single-handedly, convince me and the group I was with to look elsewhere for our entertainment and libations. Honestly, a bouncer generally has little to do with the inside venue quality, and the nature of their jobs is a tough one. As such, I'm sure I (and most reasonable human beings out there) are willing to take bouncer-treatment with a grain of salt. They have to deal with a lot of pricks, and thus the rest of us must stomach treatment of the lowest common denominator. Generally, this is a straightforward concept, and as such I'm willing to take a fair amount of shit to just get into the bar du jour.

But this guy was an over-the-top dick to all of us, for apparently no reason. We could see inside, and the place wasn't crowded; on a Saturday night, they could have used our business. I'm absolutely sure that the profits from just our group would have paid this dumb-asses salary for at least the evening. Or, better yet, a nicer dude to take his place. Either way, when the guy outside your bar is losing the establishment money for no apparent reason, you have an HR problem. Dude, just sit, check IDs, and be merry.

I wish I could say I'm pissed off, but it's really more just sad. Sad that I didn't get to visit one of my favorite spots, and sad that said spot is losing money because of a bad hiring choice. And the worst: they probably don't know it. Here's to hoping the owners of John Colins read yelp, and my chances of once again getting to enjoy a martini at their fine establishment.
author: Aaron H.

description:
This is one of my favorite chill-yet-trendy-but-casual bars in the city.  I've been here for happy hour multiple times, but I ventured here one Saturday night after a disappointing start at Boss, and was very surprised to see this place spilling with people.  I guess I never thought that a popular weekday FiDi hangout would be just as popular on the weekends.  Prices of drinks are on par with neighboring bars, but because it's always so packed, it can get tough getting a hold of a bartender.  They have funny flicks showing on their big screen, and the music they play on the weekends is awesome.  If you're lucky enough to snag a spot on their leather booth seats and ottomans, you can stay here for hours chatting away with friends.

I hate that they only have one bathroom for the ladies though.  Don't they know that girls are always lining up at the bathroom and take forever?  I guess that's why the men's bathroom here is an impromptu unisex bathroom on busy nights...
author: Diane L.

description:
We're a good fit, me and John Colins.  Great bartenders pouring strong drinks in a cool space that feels intimate and lofty at the same time.  

But during happy hour, the place fills up FAST.  One minute, I'm enjoying a nice conversation with friends at the bar then five o clock hits and bam! the yuppie bus unloaded in front and the place was packed to the gills.  Accompanying the suits came suitcases filled with attitude.

As in any bar that's crowded, drinks were spilling everywhere, toes were being stepped on, body parts bumping into another, chick fights breaking out... well almost, I was the bigger person and walked away.  

I still like you John and I did meet some cool people there.  I will be back soon but most likely after happy hour when the insecure drunk bitches get back on their short buses headed to the marina.  Ouch.  (apologies to all the secure kind people living in the marina)
author: mia s.

description:
Update:

Last night a DJ saved my life.... 

and that DJ was DJ Kash E spinning and mixing all sorts of funky beats!
_____________________________________________________

You see, the 'S' is for super, and the 'U' is for unique 
The 'P' is for perfection and you know that we are freaks 
The 'E' is for exotic, and the 'R' is for raps 
So tell those nosy people just to stay the hell back 

SUPERSONIC!!!!

umm, this place had me feeling like I was 20 again. ... the music was straight from the 90's, the DJ's were off da hook. Jason the Bartender is a cutie and a trooper for making all those fresh mint mojito's for my out-of-town friends. Folks are friendly and we had a BLAST (from the past). Although, the girls that they hired to dance on the bar, while cute, had no rhythm at all. Shoooo, if you're gonna be a go-go girl, at least try and fake like you can dance.
author: Chum L.

description:
Uh.. maybe 3.5 stars?  
I switched back and forth between 3 and 4 for a while but in the end my love of rum and cocktails in general won out and tipped the balance to 4.

I think Nicole C's review is dead on.   The music was awful  - though I think I objected more to the complete inconsistency than the inappropriate volume.
 
Then why the 4 stars?
JC carries lots of rum!   I am sooo sick of going to bars that stock 40 kinds of vodka and 2 kinds of rum (worse it is usually barcardi and captain morgan's spiced rum).  

I talked with Colin last night and he really knows and (more importantly) appreciates rum!  Plus everything he poured was perfect!  Dolly's black cherry drink was brilliant!!
author: lisa g.

description:
We are AT teh space. That means they have FREE wifi. So if you need to still get your Yelp pr0n on you can do it while you get your drunk on.

This is the Yelp DYL. 50% of the space tonight is thanks to Yelp. Hear that management? We can make or break you. Fear not. You're getting 5 stars. Good drinks. Good bartenders. Bathroom lines suck, but hey that's what pissing in the alley of Minna is for right? Wrong, but yes.

Good mixed crowd. Good ambiance and a very good venue if you're in the media gulch. Regardless a well stocked bar with a very bright and open venue if you're around early enough to see daylight.
author: R B.

description:
Although it was a Tuesday night and the place was not bouncing with energy, I really feel for the quirky art, awesome shooters and totally friendly bartenders.

Highlights:
- really nice bouncer, he loves watches so just start chatting it up 
-location is hidden and provides an intimate touch
-the art on the walls is tripy and easily sparks conversations 
-sit at the bar for a traditional feel or lay low in soft chairs and couches with candles on the table tops
-try the peach signature drink (name is currently escaping me) it has fresh mint and is yum yum yum 
-drinks are priced fairly

Sweet place in SoMA!
author: Theresa T.

description:
Came here for a friend's birthday bash.

We arrive at about 10pm on a Saturday night. It wasn't full - yet. I must say this place is a bit nicer than their older location. Major space upgrade!

The decor was pretty nice - almost typical for a lounge. The bartenders were very attentive even though there were loads of people starting to crowd around. Prices are what you'd expect from a lounge in the downtown area. 

I music wasn't bad, but it wasn't great that night. You can tell when people are having fun when they dance to the beats. But it was pretty obvious when people hated a song, people would suddenly stop or slow down and begin to chatter amongst themselves.

I'd go back..
author: Tim S.

description:
I need to get over my 3* or less reviews so let me honor John Colins since I love it. 

So far I have had so many great times here and for some reason it is the only bar where I can stand hanging out even though it gets crowded. The drinks are big and usually pretty strong. 

One star off for the hangover feelings the night of and the next day.... some people might think that should call for an extra star but that would be too simple... not that easy to get 5stars in my book.
pah! ;)
author: Doro P.

description:
It seemed as if all of the FiDi crowd came here after work on Thursday. This place was packed.

I had a cosmo to start off with and I swear my glass was full. But after playing bumper booty while trying to get back to my seat,  my cosmo was half empty. So was I. 

It's a real cozy bar though, and the brick walls are inviting. I normally don't yelp about the crowds, but the people here were cool and fun. (We bumped into my boyfriend's coworkers so that gives JC another star)
author: Vanessa W.

description:
I really like this place, but it just gets way too crowded during the whole happy hour scene. It's hard to get a drink and everyone is sort of just fumbling into each other. I experienced one too many awkward male on male body touches. They should really name this place "Excuse me Bro." 

This bar is much easier to enjoy (really good hip hop) when the corporate crowd thins out a bit later in the night.
author: Trevor P.

description:
Came here for the first time last night and I love this place! The decor is very industrial with the red brick walls. It's really comfortable to lounge with friends since they have couches every where that you can sit on. 

Everyone who came in was super TALL for some reason and there were many good looking people around ranging from 30-40 years old. :) That's always a plus. 

The bartenders were nice and the drinks weren't that expensive and the music was great, They play hip hop from back in the days. 

Can't ask for anything more!
author: Cynthia C.

description:
I have never stayed at John Collins past 7:30pm. This is definitely a happy hour joint, and a mediocre one at that. With all the other SOMA & FiDi bars, I don't understand how this one gets soooo busy. And it's always filled with the yuppier-than-thou types, which gets annoying. While it's completely packed with people, it's quite disconnected--probably just different coworkers in their own little groups like myself and mine. 

The decor in this place is very lounge-like, the music is cool & the bartenders are quick to pour...thus JC gets 3 stars for that. Oh, and the surf videos! Nice touch.

Chances are I will visit again, but only because a coworker or two insists upon that instead of a nice & dirty dive bar. Hell...If they are buying, I am not about to turn down a free drink. Really, it's just the crowd I'm not hip with...the place itself is pretty cool.
author: matt m.

description: Dark and Stormies! I love this place for happy hour. Great environment, great drinks, and plenty of room. Upscale but casual, if that makes sense? One of my favorite happy hour places in the FiDi.
author: Erin P.

description:
This is a great Happy Hour, pre-party or after the party spot. The bouncers and bartenders are so friendly and the place is usually pretty busy with no wait to get in.

I love the music here too but I am not a fan of the John Collins drink---Its basically John Collins version of a Long Island but worse. It promises to get you drunk though!
author: Krystle M.

description: This place is super super packed! But i love it! Cheap drinks, hip hop all night and not bad looking people. The only con is the over capacity! They have a really long bar area and a really small dance floor. But the majority of people there seems to just want to hang out and chill, so the bar area was full of people smashed into each other trying to get a drink. The bartenders were fast and made sure they got to everyone. One thing i really love about this place is they have a little hot dog stand guy right out side! I don't have to go far for food after dancing my ass off!
author: Bhanie C.

description:
what can i say about the JC that hasn't been said?  JC is dope.  great happy hour spot, reasonably priced drinks, just a little bit out of FiDi proper so you won't get too many d-bags in suits here (u know the type).   it's also a great party spot later on if u wants to shine, now throw your hands up in the skkyyy....

and did i mention the reasonably priced drinks?  I think I once ordered 6 drinks for $35 (non-happy hour).  not bad for SF.
author: Toby C.

description:
My girls and I took our bachelorette here last Saturday and we all had a really good time. I don't know if it was just me and the drinks the bartender was throwing at me, but everyone in this lounge looked really happy! lol. Seriously... When I finally looked up from my empty glass, it was all smiles, everywhere! 
The bartender was on point. As soon as we sat down, he's was taking in our orders. No wait time at all. I loved that! I don't remember exactly what kind of music they were playing, but there was a DJ at this lounge. The music was good enough for all of us to hit the dance floor after we got our alcoholic beverages! We had a blast! The security was even great! They weren't dicks! I go to plenty of lounges, bars and clubs and security guards do not like to deal with overly intoxicating and loud women, but Mike held it down! lol...  Overall, our night was memorable! I will be coming back, soon. This time, I might bring a date! So your bartenders could get him on a level thats uncontrollable. 
And I can take him home and take advantage! That's what I'm talkin' about!
author: Jackie O.

description:
Worst service I've encountered in San Francisco.  Stiffed at the bar after I'd laid down my tip with $20 in hand.  The snarky girl bartender decided to fill about 7 other orders instead of mine while the other chucklehead bar staff just hit on females within leering distance.

I realize I may not be a billionaire playboy with looks to match, but most establishments have the decency to exchange their liquor for my money.  0 stars.
author: K M.

description:
WARNING: This is Sausage Fest Central, so if you're a dude looking for ladies, I'd suggest going elsewhere.  Since I'm not a dude, nor am I looking for ladies, John Collins hit the spot for happy hour for our group of 7.  We had to wait a few minutes to grab a prime seating area (seating is actually pretty scarce here...), but once we sat down, we were able to enjoy a very laid back atmosphere.  The bartender was very sweet (I love being called "sweetheart" by bartenders.  Don't know why, but I do...) and made our drinks STIFF.  Comin' back fo sho.

FYI - it's a really random crowd - I didn't see any "hot guys" as mentioned in previous reviews.  But, truly, that's all right if you're not looking for a meat market.
author: Kira K.

description:
Stellar staff here!  I was in line for the bathroom and a staff member cut in front of me only to make sure everything was in order.  What?  You mean you wanted to provide us drunkards a refill of TP?  You wanted  to wipe down the toilet seat sprinkled with pee?  You wanted to sweep the floor so our heels wouldn't be dragging wet TP?  Will you marry me?!??

The service didn't stop there!  Trays of hor dourves were offered from neighboring Osha Thai to keep the patrons happy.  Bartenders actually make eye contact with the little chick 2 rows back hoping for a vodka tonic.  Yes, me?  You choose me?  Tear.

Drinks from their bar menu are inventive but I'd recommend your usuals.  They mix them with soju/sake and those tend to be weak.  

The crowd is pretty mixed and friendly.  One in particular was really friendly to the point where he wanted to extend a penis and shake your hand!  Yes, a couple was dancing and the guy had pitched a tent and about 10 scouts could live under it.  His date must have noticed it, because she made it a point to dance 6 inches + another 6 inches apart from him at all times.  And she just kept shuffling back, back, back until she ran out of dance space.  At the opportune time when she had her eyes closed and her back to his flagpole, he shoved his hand in there to tuck it down.  Like Silence of the Lambs???  I dunno what you guys do in those situations.  It was good entertainment for my friends and I who had a good eye level's view of the dancing bone.

Coincidentally, "Scarface" was playing on the wall.  "Say HELLO to mah lil fren!"  Hello.........................
author: Chris T.

description:
John Collins is our go-to happy hour spot.  Birthday? JC, Promotion? JC, Goodbye party? JC.  Easy choice.  It's close to work, has great drinks, a good atmosphere, and - at times - some decent eye candy.

The key to JC is to grab the upstairs lounge spot at 6pm or so, and hang til they kick you out.  It has this crazy funky wallpaper that makes you feel like you're either in a really cheesy hotel or in the tropics (mostly the former...).

I do remember being here one time with a friend and asking him to find out if the bartender was single... It never hurts to have something good to look at while you're waiting for a drink.
author: Caitlin D.

description:
Love it...I finally found a damn neighborhood bar not overrun by bridge and tunnel cats. Good music, and the staff wants to be there. It's a mixture of post work, happy hour mixed into a small locals scene. The bar staff are friends so you feel that when you walk in.

I've been there 3 times:
-Once was an afternoon visit. i ponied up tot he bar and read a book. The bartender kept my drink filled the whole session.
- I went there on the one year anniversary and it was off the chain. Good DJs, and they didn't care that me and my friends were super casual.
-One night before I went to Harlot which really sucked. I wished we stayed at J.Collins;)
author: Bill M.

description: DJ kind of sucked. The drinks are expensive and the place gets crowded. The dance floor is pretty small and there isn't that many restrooms available. i think I'd like this place if there were better music playing.
author: tracey l.

description:
Back in the day in "The City", before most of these "yelpers" moved here or when they thought San Francisco was just Fisherman's Wharf, this was truly a  great diverse city. We didn't have all these Elitists, Transplants who think they are City folk, and separatists acting like teenagers. Have you ever heard the expression, "you can't judge a book by it's cover?"  Did they teach that where you're from? 
That being said John Colins is a true old skool "San Francsico" bar. Everyone is welcome! From the Stripe Shirts to the T-Shirts, Straight Blondes to the Afros, Tall ones, skinny ones, fat  ones, green ones, and shooby dooby do ones. Hip Hop, 80's, Soul, Reggae, Rock, Ska, Electro,Punk... John Colins is "Everyday People" .
Rock on with your badself JC!  Herb Caen would be proud. See Ya on Friday and Saturday Nights where I always end my evening! Mahalo Nui Loa!
author: Kool K.

description:
I have this real unique condition.  I am a social drinker but there is a fine line where I get a bit anti-social.  I love being out and about, but I avoid being in crowded places.  Maybe I just value my personal space a little differently.  

Walked in on a weeknight, like around 7:30 and the place was a little busy but not uncomfortable.  The bar was pretty full and there was a slight wait there to get drinks.  A small group of us found a spot amongst the posh lounging area.  Dim lighting, loft-like space and decent music all contributed to a relaxed vibe.  Drinks filled to the brim but a little weak for the price.  

9:30 rolls around and the place thins out significantly.  The DJ is now spinning straight mellow hip hop with a jazz flavor and now the place got really comfortable for me.  It's just too bad we were all getting a little hungry and the drinks just weren't doing it for me, so we bailed.  But nice to know I've got a spot on the weeknights, just got to wait for the "happy hour" crowd to end.
author: D.wight L.

description:
John Colins, commonly refered to as "that place near Zebulon" has rapidly become one of my favorite happy hour spots.  The skylights, combined with the brick walls and spacious ceilings make this a fun and happy place, especially after you've had a few of their most excellent cocktails.

Named after the two owners, named John and Colin, who are always there.  Half the time they intimidate me and half the time I think they're gay together, in that macho surfer kind of way.  Everyone always talks about how they give patrons free drinks, but it hasn't happened to me yet.  Still give it 5 stars, though.

I would like to point out that I'm writing this review while I'm hanging off the side of my bed with my keyboard and monitor on the floor.
author: Jackson R.

description:
This is a great spot for happy hour or a drink on a weeknight. The vibe is very chill, the decor is strangely tropical but at least different, and the space is large with high ceilings. The crowd always seems to be having a good time. We came here once on a weeknight and staged a dance off which everyone got in on. 
 
My only complaint is that the music is way too loud. I don't know if the DJ didn't get enough attention as a child but he certainly seems to be demanding it now. We actually had to leave this place once because we couldn't hear a word our friends were saying without them yelling at the top of their lungs. I will begrudgingly put up with this nonsense at a club, but to deal with it at a bar is unacceptable. 
 
Come for the happy hour. I'd recommend checking out the place later as well, just be prepared to have your vocal cords take a beating.
author: Shreya C.

description: Random crowd of 30's to 40's. Liked the upstairs loft that looked over everything and the painting of the pitbull on the wall - bunch of randomness.
author: Linda H.

description:
By far the best bar in the city... it truly is my Cheers - but for good reason! First and most importantly, I can always count on being given something new and tasty... Gotta love the sweet touch of a flower being put in it, too! After relishing my satisfying cocktails and then heading out for a little dancing at nearby Fluid (!), I can't even count how many times I've stumbled back to good ol' JC's and have continued the good times :) 
It is quite obvious that the entire staff has a lot of pride in this bar - I've seen the long hours that are spent to keep it in tip-top shape. The decor is great - the new addition of the upstairs alcove is perfect for chatting it up with the DJ... and some nice dark corners ;) I also think this is one of the only places in sf where EVERYONE is welcome. From the ladies in prom dresses to the bad boys with mohawks, John, Colin, and the rest of the bartenders really make everyone feel at home... oh yea and dont forget to vote for John Colins on Aol CityGuide for "Best Cocktails" It's about damn time the city recognized what an amazing place (with amazing people) John Colins is!!
author: Mia B.

description:
Great place to grab a few drinks if you're not up for a club scene. The crowd varies depending on the time and night you go, but from what I've seen, there's a good mix that finds their way to this little spot. 

I do appreciate that the floors aren't sticky and there's no cover at the door as well - which makes this an automatic gem after perusing the grimy little holes around the city. Happy hour is great it too!
author: mara l.

description: This bar seemed to have a bit of an identity crisis. Is it a cocktail lounge? A club? A laid back happy hour spot? It seemed like it was trying to be all three of these things, and it didn't really work. That being said though, the drinks were pretty good, and really cheap, so I certainly can't complain. I forget what night we were there (I think either Monday or Tuesday), but all drinks were $2 off, which you really can't beat considering how cheap the drinks were to begin with.
author: Allyson P.

description:
I saw the reviews about this place...average of 4 stars? Wow, some of you Yelpers are wayyyyyyy too generous. 

Bouncers - kinda rude, if you ask me.

Bar service - can't complain; bartenders are pretty quick

The crowd - meh. It's usually a mix I don't really care for because it gets so damn confusing sometimes. You have the college kids (the ones who have been attending college for 6+ years and can't ever graduate) in their backpacks (very classy). Then you have the yuppie types in their fancy Thomas Pink shirts and ties. And then you have the artsy folks in their dreadlocks. Kinda like a weird psychedelic dream when you people-watch here...

I don't think I've lasted more than 10 minutes at this place before wanting to leave and go across the street to Zebulon.
author: Blenda L.

description:
Super fun (like, oh my god!), loungy/but still upbeat bar. There's no room for dancing, which is why the minus 1 star, but they play some great music. 

PERFECT for happy hour or hanging out either before or after a club. The bartenders are attentive and nice. I promise you, even though there's always a crowd, you will get served quickly.
author: Ali L.

description:
Now that I am a true SoManiac, I will be obliging to meet anyone here for a post-drudge drink M-F.  I went last Saturday to meet up with some folks and I really liked the atmosphere.  Whenever I am with friends (who are entertaining), I don't really pay attention to the people around me (who aren't entertaining), so whatever.  I liked the music, people were having a good time, their cucumber cooler cocktail was refreshing (oooahhh), the bouncer was very nice and a gentleman (not the norm round these parts, I'm afraid).   The people... I met a very lovely girl in line for the bathroom and we had a great conversation about some psycho who was trying to psychoanalyze her as his pick-up tactic.  I also met a very rude young lady in line for the bathroom and I was obliged to sass her right back.  You know, whatever again.

The best part was that they were showing the movie that my friend Brittney sent me a clip of.  The subject of the email was, "It's Van Damme Friday!"  The movie involves dancing on a basketball court, eighties leotards (cameltoe, anyone?), and JCVD as an extra (cameltoe, anyone!?!?).  Sweet.
author: Jessica M.

description:
i really enjoyed my experience here. No cover, no dress code, plenty of seating.....it's cool. 

i love that there's always a mature diverse crowd of 25-35ers. Its a great atmosphere....a bit hidden in an alleyway, but very chic, reasonable drink prices, friendly bartenders.

If you come here on a fri or sat night, be sure to get there a bit early, IF you want seats.

Definitely coming back for happy hour or late night drink
author: Dessa R.

description:
My now-husband and I had our first date (which was not a date) here so I gotta love this place, don't I? But seriously, it's a great bar. I also had my good-bye drinks here when I left my previous company and the crew was so helpful and friendly with reserving us the upstairs and treated us like VIPs which was nice.
I love the atmosphere in there, the music and the projections on the wall. A great place, not too chic, not too dive-y. Just right.
author: Alexandra D.

description:
Don't let the back alley facade of John Colins trick you into not going.  Tiny Natoma Street may have a rundown appearance, but all this negativity ends, quite literally, at the door of John Colins, one of SOMA's finer nightlife establishments.

First, I was truly dumbstruck by the congeniality and pleasant disposition of the bouncers.  Generally, bouncers are an odious lot, surly trolls risen from the mire, bred solely to prey upon the good spirits of San Francisco's weekend socialites.  Getting frisked and interrogated by a grim looking half-ogre is more than enough to sour a person's mood for the evening.  However, the way the John Colins bouncers joked around with each guest made me want to have a good time there.  Kudos to these fine gents.

To even enter the four- or five-star category, a club has to have no cover charge.  John Colins gets a huge helping of these "mad props" I keep hearing about for having no cover.

Inside, John Colins is small and charming.  A dark curtain hangs over the main entrance.  Large works of abstract art adorn brick walls, against which sit couches for lounging.  There's a projector that shows random movies on the wall.  Last Saturday night they were showing "Breakin'", truly one of the finer pieces of breakdancing cinema from the early 80s, surpassed only by its eponymous sequel, "Breakin' 2: Electric Boogaloo".  A little electric boogaloo certainly would have garnered a five-star rating, no questions asked.

The bar area is narrow and a point of some serious congestion.  Despite this, I was able to get my drinks relatively quickly, though at a serious premium.  I guess this is where they get their money back on having a coverless club, but at least I can control how much I drink in any given night (in theory, anyway).  The drinks themselves were fine.  Nothing special, nothing terrible.

The music.  Ah, the music!  A great mix of (predominantly) old and new school hip hop, with a smattering of pop-infused electronica.  Light on tannins, with a round, smooth finish reminiscent of blackberries and dark chocolate.

Finally, the crowd was almost entirely Asian as it was some Asian girl's birthday party.  The only other time I've been here was for an Indian party, in which case the place was overrun by brown folk.  It's hard to comment on the clientele with such limited data, but at least everyone seemed pretty friendly on both occasions and were intent on having a good time.  And the place wasn't full to the brim with a bunch of jokers, so there was plenty of room to stand comfortably without having to feel someone's anus pressed against your thigh (I mean, I can do that at home, right?).

I really enjoyed my time at John Colins.  I will advocate on its behalf on the next evening of carousal and general merriment.
author: Rajiv B.

description:
For the hr that I was there last night, this place is a blast! I really had a great time! The trick is to make sure you are there early so that you can get a table or seat. This place was rockin by 6:30!! Bartenders were super nice, which is always a plus. I would for sure go back! 

Plus the open floor plan lends itself moving around and mingling.
author: Nicole F.

description: Friendly bartenders.  It can get pretty crowded on weekends.  Skip the sake-based mojito - unless you like sweet drinks.
author: Kristen S.

description:
Cool little brick bar in SOMA to grab a drink after work.  Their drinks are well priced and its usually not too crowded.  However, if you're looking for a place to dance, I wouldn't recommend this spot.  Its too small and the crowd usually isn't coming here to do that.  Its more of a place to unwind after a long day at work and enjoy living the life in the city.

For a cool factoid, Baron Davis from the Golden State Warriors lives next to John Collins.  So on occasion, you will see Warrior players there hanging out.
author: Herman N.

description:
As I was trying to get my third mojito of the night the hot bartendress said that they were out of mojitos.  Out?  Out?

Whiskey?  Tango?  Foxtrot?  

I haven't been at a bar that's "run out" of a drink since I was in a bar in Guangzhou and when we tried to order some tequila (referred to as "Mexican Strong Wine" in China, no really) and the bardude sheepishly told us they were out.

I did get my ass grabbed a pleasant number of times here though, so there's that working for John Collins.
author: Beau G.

description:
If you were there the night I was there, you would have been entertained by the drunk Happy Hour to Last Call shirt & tie guy yelling at his GF, and I quote:

"YOU NEED TO F***ING QUIT BEING A CONTROLLING A$$HOLE AND LET ME DRINK!!!"

Her face after that, priceless! The poor girl. Then there was that other group of friends trying to cut in front of the girls restroom line, because their friend  (who they were carrying) needed to use the room pretty bad. It was then that it occurred to me. Either these folks poor a stiff one, or people here have some serious drinking problems. In one night I almost saw vomit and domestic violence.....other than that, this place is pretty cool, I like it alot and think you will too....especially if you know the story with the naming of the John Colins drink. Clever.
author: M S.

description:
I love saying to the bartender:  "I'll have a John Collins at John Colins please! Har har har!  Get it?  Get it?"

The look I always get is either:  "Yeah, like I haven't heard that one before."  or  "I haven't heard that one before, you big weird dork."
author: Liz C.

description:
Douchebag city! 
Lots of guys calling each other "bro", hi-fiving for no reason, doing complicated sequential fist bumps (bring it together, lock it up n twist, kaboom!) obnoxious bar-side manner, ordering yeager /patron shots and yelling at each other "YOU READY? Bring it!!"   The time I was there they got absolutely wasted and helped themselves to some birthday celebrant's party hors d'oeuvres, I was disgusted, everyone was disgusted.  As I was driving home, I realized that my friends are real douchebags.  

Great music, great staff and 4 stars for putting up with us!
author: JJ J.

description: John Colins is a staple for Happy Hour joints in the city. This is our go to place and it is always a good time. The bartenders are friendly and mix drinks well. The crowd is mixed, but mostly an after work crowd. I love how they give flowers with their drinks.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Last week, my roommate alerted me that he was coming here for a friend's birthday party and I would be attending as well.  Not being a huge fan of the club scene of SOMA, I put up a valiant, yet ultimately unsuccessful fight to get out of venturing to this unknown establishment.  As I rode the dingy 38 into town with the eclectic mix of crack heads and old Asian people, I dreaded the worst: power tripping bouncers, $30 covers, sausage fests, attractive yet bitchy ladies and an overall disappointing night as these elements have comprised the majority of my SOMA nights.  

John Collins completely surprised me.  The bouncers were cordial and smiling, the bartender was attentive and respectful.  The majority of the clientele was approachable, laid back, well dressed, attractive (but not pretentious) and fun.  The music was loud, but not so loud that it was impossible to carry on a conversation.  The place was crowded, but not a clusterfuck.  The drinks were strong and delicious.  Bizarre movies (Scarface, weird aerobic 80's dancing movies with levitating brooms) were projected onto the area above the door which at least made for an interesting conversation piece as well as something to look at when you were stuck with no one to talk to.  To further improve my impression of JC, I believe I had the scientifically perfect combination of Jaeger and Gin and Tonics flowing through my bloodstream.

John Colins has convinced me that there is actually a cool place to hang out in SOMA.  I will definitely come here again and I'd recommend it to anyone who wants a chill place to enjoy your Saturday night.  Furthermore, I've learned that I should never write off a neighborhood of the city because of a few bad experiences and unfriendly people.
author: Patrick N.

description:
Love this place.  Happy hours it's the place to be.  And surprisingly, even post happy hour times it's pretty awesome too.  

It does get very crowded and it's hard to move at times.  So if you're holding on too tight and you've lost the edge - I wouldn't be a regular patron here.  Getting drinks and the bartender's attention can be challenging at times considering almost half the place is the bar itself!  Just imagine their tough jobs of serving pretty much half of the people in there..considering once you walk in and take 5 steps you're at the bar already!

Very chill, islandy-feeling.  Both John and Colins are my homies.  And together - we're all BFFs!
author: Yup S.

description:
The John Colins experience is almost perfectly in sync with what the name implies.  It is a semi-upscale joint with no-nonsense service and decor, with a hint of fancy.  Note the one L when you try to google for this place.

My bar experience was mixed.  There was a bus boy that came over three times to explain the bartender was busy, then finally after 30 minutes I had drink orders filled three times over.  Whether you get a drink or not is apparently hit or miss.  Beyond that annoyance, the bar is mellow, perfectly lit, and full of gorgeous upper-class people.  I came on a Thursday night and it was predominantly packed with Asian women (whoo!).

Seems like a perfect place to network and enjoy a happy hour, people-watching the hours away.
author: niero g.

description:
Met my first Yelpers here yesterday and had a great time (props to Lauren S, Caitlin, Matthew S, Celeste L, and Luis M for meeting up with me there).

The space is excellent first of all and my style for sure. Very high ceilings, exposed brick, candles a-blazin' and good artwork on the walls. The happy hour is obviously what draws people in and for good reason. The prices were good and it's a relaxing cool space to chill out in.

It got crowded quick in there though so be prepared for the typical "squeeze-your-way" to the bathroom routine but that's gonna happen just about anywhere that's worth a damn to hang out in.

I'll be back.
author: Gabriel R.

description:
I Admit it. I review Bars, Lounges and clubs based on the party I'm with. I'll try not to with this one. 

Place seems pretty chill. I think the owner has an obsession with pit bulls because that's all there is in the brick walls. Music was a mix from new school to Michael Jackson old School on a Saturday Night.
