Dress code is relaxed - I was able to get in rockin my Jabbawockee shirt and Dunks - but the men had to tuck in their shirts. lol. 

Drinks were alright - I ordered my regular red corona and the dumbass bartender put TABASCO in my shit - I was like wtf? and gave it back to him. "It's Corona + grenadine syrup+ a shot of vodka yah dimwit." DAMN. 

The ladies room was kept clean the whole night I was there and big ups to the ladies that 'go'. The line moved WAY faster than the mens. So +1 star for that. 

They're pretty strict with the smokers outside - you must stay on the side walk and can't yell. WHY? Coz Baron Davis lives right accross. Nice.
author: Michelle B.

description:
best gimlets in the city.

nuff said.
author: Josie M.

description:
Happy hour every weeknight from 5-7.  Happy hour all night on Mondays.  A great place in the SOMA to start or end the night.  Great atmosphere and decor with an excellent group of clientele.

So come for the drinks and stay for the company, if you're lucky enough to secure a seat.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Cool little bar - the night we were there the DJ was playing mash-up - usually totally annoying, but it kept the vibe going in this place.
It's a nice intimate place where you can have a one on one convo or bring a group and have a little celebration.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Love this place.
Best happy hour ever.
Go now.
Run.
Don't walk.
You will love it too.
How could you not.
Laid back atmosphere.
Great drinks.  
Good crowd.  
Skiing and surfing on the weird projector.  
A bartender (John) that I was trying to get my sister to hit on.  
Can't beat it.  
Loves it.
Go to Osha afterward for delicious food.
Seeya.
author: Derek B.

description:
Definitely my new favorite bar!  
Even if you think you've had it with the bar scene, give John Colins a try.  Can't really say anything different from what's already been said, but the room is lofty and spacious, with a nice mix of seating and they mix up a good, strong drink!

Maybe my opinion was swayed because I went with a big group of regulars who knew all the staff, and they passed their love of John Colins on to me.  Or maybe I was just won over by the crazy dvd's they were projecting on to the wall: Graffiti Rock (an early 80's hip=hop version of American Bandstand).  
http://www.oldschoolhiphop.com/video/graffitirock.htm
 Buy this dvd, you won't stop laughing.

And go to John Colins, you won't regret it!
author: Becca V.

description: This place is totally chill, cool music, chill crowd! The drinks were ok, my only thing would be DONT EVER serve me a shot out of a mini boot! Who does that? It was awkard to take and had to take 2 gulps cause I had to turn it to get the rest out of the toe area. ??? Otherwise id totally go here for a kick back night on the town.
author: Bee B.

description:
With 200+ reviews under its belt, there's not much to add here when it comes to describing the ambiance, types of peeps you'll find, yadda yadda.  But I'll still throw in my $0.02:

A great, casual place for a drink or ten to hang with your friends and mingle with the locals when your hotel is nearby.  I haven't found anyone to be snooty like some say and my drinks are always stiff.  Nice.  It does help that one of the owners went to your high school. ;)  209 represent!
author: Joy P.

description:
I say, Five Stars for my boyfriend dj Esquire and his friends DJs ExtraLars and CitizenTen's awesome sets.  Minus One Star for the annoying dudes that hangout right by the stairway, causing it to be a potential fire hazard, and for their lack of chivalry when I am just trying to get upstairs.  Please dudes, pull your untucked striped "going out" shirts-wearing, baggy faded denim-wearing butts away from the stairway entry!  

(thank you)
author: Annster L.

description: We went here on Halloween since they advertised no cover.  It's located in an alley way and hard to find if you don't know your way around the city.  The place was packed of course, and extremely hot with no A/C, but only a single ceiling fan operating.  Limited seats and couches for people to rest their feet, especially us women & our heels.  The beers were only $3; although, specialty drinks cost as much as the W Hotel nearby.  I heard this place has a surfer-vibe, but on this night, they were playing normal videos and hip hop music, with go-go dancers on the bar shaking it.  On a non-Halloween night, I'm sure this place is pretty laid back.
author: Christine R.

description:
I went to John Colins on Friday for a company sponsored Happy Hour. It was a bit scene-y and a bit of a meat market but not too bad considering it is smack in the middle of the FiDi. The space is nice and they have a lot of specialty drinks- my friend had the Effing Black Cherry something or other- I stole a sip and it was really good. I stuck with wine because I have a tendency to suck down yummy liquor concoctions too fast for my own good, and I try to maintain a semblance of responsible drinking when the COO of my company is around.

I would recommend getting there early - they open at 5 - so you can stake a claim to some space and not have to stand around in the cattle pen of the bar.
author: Angie R.

description:
We went to John Collins on Friday the 13th! Again I found out about a new place on Yelp and wanted to give it a shot. We ordered a couple of specialty drinks and a Martini. 
PAST (Price/Ambiance/Service/Timing) ranking on a 1-5 basis
P: 5/5 - excellent price for a bar in downtown SF. You might find cheaper drinks, but come on, a Grey Goose Martini for under $10 is very good (not during HH)
A: 3/5 - Ambiance was Good for the location
S: 4/5 - Service was good. Good quality drinks, kind/listening/patient waitress
T:  4/5 - Timing was good enough so you get your 2nd drink when you need it :)

Overall: 4/5.
Do I recommend it? Absolutely
Do I come back? Definitely
Any suggestions? It would be nice to serve a limited menu of finger foods. I know the specialty is in drinks, but some light appetizers could make a great compliment.
author: sohrab a.

description: The essence of a great bar in my opinion all in one! Even on a an unplanned Friday night, John Colins is a must-hit-up bar for the night.. we tend to plan that we'll leave after two rounds of drinks, but we usually just end up staying... RIGHT ON for great music, quick and efficient bar tenders, easy parking, close location to 111 Minna so we can pre-drink before attending an event there, and three thumbs up for the awesome crowd...
author: Chrysantha C.

description: I LOVE John Colins. At 5 p.m. I Like John Colins at 6 p.m. I can tolerate John colins at 7 p.m. The party's over at John Colins come 7:30. I love love love the new space and I love love love the Vin Diesel look-alike bartender who I'm pretty sure I propositioned after my 4th vodka soda last night (sorry, iceman). This is definitely the place to meet fidi hotties with good jobs and peter pan syndrome if that's the sort of thing you like. I do. Just come early to beat the crowds and get a place at the bar. Leave before the place is so packed you can't get a drink but will likely have one spilled on you.
author: Autumn K.

description:
E-props to a bar that plays old B&W nudie films on the giant flat screen above.
We wouldn't have even noticed it save for the drunk come-and-get-me-gyrating Asian cutie yelling out BOOBIES (which prompted just about everyone to turn and look up)
This being our second time there, we've gotten to know a little more about it
It's a perfect post Osha Thai go out for some more drinks destination as it's just a hop, skip and a jump over a street sleeper around the corner.
As others have written, pre-clubbing stop for the trendy 2nd and Minna area (a lof of non obvious clubs around)
Crowd was a mix of 20-40yr olds, and most were easy on the eyes
Bouncer carded all of our NY driver licensed group and said welcome (a nice touch)
It is not that big, so it does get crowded, but there are couches and a small upstairs
Place itself looks like a trendied out old repair garage or barn
Only gripe is that it get's hot in there, needs more ventilation / AC (after all it's not Sun afternoons @ Body and Soul in NYC where it's so warm the mixed crowd has to strip down and slurp waters/redbulls while thizzin the day away)

PS: I upped some iphone snagged shots of aforementioned of Black and White naughty vids. There's something inherently classy about old skool boobies
author: G K.

description:
Ah, the Almighty JC. One of the best happy hour joints in the city. The ambiance is unparalleled, the crowd is never too stuffy or too classy or too suited up.

I try to steer clear of post-work happy hours as much as I can (you can drop $50 before you know what hit you & hate yourself in the morning when you look at your bank account with a pounding headache), but I make the rare exception for John Colins.
author: Pete J.

description:
A great little bar in the heart of SOMA. I have been here a few times and I must say it has always been a really fun experience. It's a rather cozy place, but you can tell that it has a flavor of its own. They play pretty good music with what I think is a small room upstairs for dancing (but I've never been there myself). And they play interesting and captivating movies on a huge screen above the door ( I have seen snowboarding/surfing videos to naked ladies). It's definitely a place you can sit down and talk to your friends since there are quite a few tables and little ottomans everywhere. Sometimes it gets a little crowded, but it has never been too unbearable. Most important thing though, not too many creepy guys lingering around and being sketchy like other places (ie: The Dirty Martini). 

The bartenders here are absolutely great and so are the drinks! I came here twice for friends' birthdays and they always give you a free round of shots for everyone in your party or free drinks. My favorite drink here is the Leilani. It's a total girly drink, but absolutely delicious.

It's a good place to unwind with a group of friends, probably a good place to start your barhopping adventure for the night.
author: Angela L.

description:
Stop luring me with your crispy,golden mixture of goldfish and lightly salted pretzels....and your oh-so-yummy-pint-sized-mint-filled-goodness of a mojito. Oh John Collins....you know me so well!

 JC (as we lazy folks like to call it....as if we're saving a breath with one syllable) is the perfect chill bar....dope beats (yes,my friend...I said "dope"),unbelievably friendly staff, comfy leather ottomans, awesome artwork (kudos to the Sam Flores piece by the DJ area), and an overall lovely ambiance for a staight-up,no bullshit, spankin good time.
author: Marivic F.

description:
Happy Hour is cheap so cheers to that!  Downside, Happy Hour is insane.  No space to move, really loud music, and plan on standing the entire time.  HOWEVER, they do pass around some free samples of their signature drink during this magical time. ^_^)b 

We actually didn't seem to mind the crowd and the noise so much.  I was with good people and the booze was cheap.  Cheap alcohol tends to make some of us all happy and giddy no matter what.  We stood and talked just fine and the crowd didn't seem to affect us much.

During nonHappy-Hour, I liked this place because it's always got some impressive artwork on the walls, good looking worker crowd, low tables to sit at for chatting, and relatively fast bartenders.
author: Mary R.

description:
Went on a pub crawl recently and this place was bar #3 (which makes it far easier to remember then say, bar #7...but that's another story!) Despite that this place is literally around the corner from my office, I have avoided it up to this point. I had a drunken adventure one night and stopped here and for some reason did not like the clientle and vowed never to return. boy, was i missing out! 

Drinks are good, bartenders are cute, and peeps were cool. Enjoy the surfing video and I hear happy hour is cheap cheap cheap. Plus, Saboo, the awesome bouncer at 111 Minna is there on Saturday nights and he humors me with his delightful conversation while reminding me to stay out of the street.  Definitely a good place to start out an evening.
author: Marissa R.

description:
Warning all sneakerheads: you can't get in after happy hour =(

Aiight, so liked the mojito I got here during happy hour with some co-workers; I liked the paintings on the main floor & the overall aesthetics; and I especially liked the fact that it's hella cutty. 

This past weekend, a group of 6 (including myself) were not really dressed up but didn't wanna spend the night at home. I mean, if there was an actual fire at your apartment building that same afternoon and the whole joint smelled like burnt tires, you wouldn't wanna stay at home either! I remembered the cutty-ass John Colins and suggested we hit it up that night. I THOUGHT I read here on Yelp that there isn't really a dress code and that you can find people in suits mixed in with people in sneaks and fitted New Eras. Umm.. I was wrong and misinformed.

Everyone in our crew except me (miracle!) was donning a pair of sneaks that night. As soon as the guy at the door sees us approaching the velvet ropes, he's like "Dress code, can't let you guys in." He points to all the Js and Dunks to make a point. "I can only let YOU in," he adds, noting that I have arrived in pumps. Right, like I'd go into the bar without my friends. Fuck I look like! 

The night wasn't a total bust, as we ended up going to Tunnel Top, sneaks and all =)
author: Iris V.

description:
I read the reviews for this place and had to stop by. 

I had invited some friends who were in town for conventions and we all fell in love with it; we came back twice in their three day stay. 

The "snow job" martini is to die for. I'm not too much of a froo froo type drinker, but this one definitely takes the cake. I will say though, have one of the guy bartenders make this because they make it perfectly. Everytime I go in now and the chick bartender makes it, she od's on the sugar rim and never puts enough pom liquer in there.

My only complaint is that if you go anytime Thu-Sat, it's tough to find a seat and then the last resort is the seating next to the restroom which is never to be desired.

Overall, I love this place! Definitely a better alternative to the other places nearby.
author: Milli A.

description:
This is a great bar! I went last night -- the bartenders were friendly, I always got a drink in under three minutes despite the busy-ness and the music was good and not so loud that you couldn't talk. 

Did I mention there were cute boys in suits? On a Saturday? Maybe it was a wedding party. Doesn't matter, they were cute and Friendly! ;) 

Only 4 stars because it was a Saturday with a good crowd, but on weekday happy hours John Collins can get overly crowded. Also, there's a $15 minimum on cards, so you have to keep a tab which is annoying but understandable.
author: Sapana S.

description:
I don't review many bars and so far zero clubs because many times it's who i'm with, or who I happen to meet that makes it into a terrific, good, or just OK night (When I'm out with friends, it can never be a bad night, right?).

However, John Colins is just such a good spot that I just have to wade in and talk about it.  It's a small cozy spot down an alley, with great artwork, movies on the wall, and is a good place to bring a date, hang out with friends, or just have a quick drink after work.  I'm a sucker for brick walls indoors, and so it's always cool when there is one behind the bar.  And then there are the drinks, which are a tad pricey but made very well.

The huge drapery/stagey entranceway is a little strange though; I still haven't  quite wrapped my head around that one.  I guess it just adds character.
author: Lemar H.

description:
I don't understand why this place is so popular.  Packed to the gills.   Lots of I-Banker types.  No dancing.  Listless-looking go-go dancers.  Cheesy, overplayed 90s hip-hop on the decks.  BO-RING.

Addendum:  I just learned that this is my company's unofficial hangout of choice.  Aiya...
author: Momo R.

description:
Our go-to place when we're sick of our other happy hours, or when we want to go out but don't want to pay cover. 

Always a good time at John Colins! 

You know I'm a fan of bars that serve champagne in mini bottles!!!
author: Beth W.

description: Interesting looking place with brick walls and all that jazz...diverse crowd. Designated dance floor with a few places to sit which is always a plus.  Music was okay..mix of top40 and some older hip hop stuff.  Limited amount of bathrooms available..I think there were like 3 bathrooms total from my drunken memory...
author: Patty O.

description:
im not quite sure if this will be a fair review or not. i went here for a korean american professional society happy hour event.  basically, it was just another reason to drink, in nicer clothes then i usually wear. the place was packed with 5' 5" northfaces so im sure this isnt the usual douchey crowd everyone talks about. 

the only real applicable points i could probably make is that they really should open the entrance area up more. is that railing an ada issue thing? and get rid of the plants there. getting all in peoples faces when all you want to do is rush the bar for a drink.

thanks ian l for letting me know about these things. i owe you a drink. 

and nameless friend of a friend that works at yelp. i better get that damn vip entrance shit next year!!
author: Euge L.

description:
Small place, always busy, very yuppity financial districty crowd. 

Even so, I like coming here occasionally and I always get a bloody mary. They put Guinness in it, which I think is interesting.

It's clean, the bartenders are nice and they always have a screen up playing random movies. Kind of expensive but what bar in the city isn't.
author: Lindsay S.

description:
These guys have nailed it on the head. When John, Colin and Leilani opened this bar over a year ago, they were facing a challenge of making it in the area already saturated with nightlife. Many tried and failed, like Varnish across the alley. Many more are doing OK, but lost their luster in the ever changing and utterly unpredictable bar popularity ranking in San Francisco.

A year later, the place is thriving. Come in at any night, and there will be people, but from Wednesday night through Saturday night, it is really happening. Which is surprising, considering that not that many people really live nearby. That means, people actually COME here on purpose. I know I do. 

Take Wednesdays, for instance. John Colins attracts the spillover crowd from 111 Minna, which for some inexplicable reason closes at 10 pm. That spells gold for the bar's owners, because people who want to carry on with their night out can just hope over round the corner.

Drinks are inventive and reasonably priced. The bar staff is friendly. In fact, the owners Colin and Leilani put their money where their mouth is by working the bar themselves. The movies shown on the screen range from big wave surfing (apparently, the bar was started with the Hawaiian idea in mind, but who cares now) to 1940s erotic flicks (indeed). The music is generally nice and loungey. The couch seat - barstool balance is just about right. The interior decor is clearly done by a professional, from the vaulted ceiling to the giant painting of bird's eye view of San Francisco. And the huge mirrors are strategically placed above the bar so that you don't have to rubberneck around singling out attractive targets. All that makes John Colins a great pickup location. 

What else can I say? This place has been good to me.
author: Evg R.

description:
This place is aite..

You enter through a velvet curtain and you'll notice people looking up above the entrance, watching the film projector.  They played random stuff from a skateboarding video to Fast Times at Ridgemont High..yeahhh..!!  

Cool art on the walls..the crowd is very unpredictable, which makes watching who comes through the velvet curtain interesting.  There was an eclectic mix of middle-aged, older crowd, pretty diverse.  They played hiphop most of the night--mostly from the 90's.  DJ's chillin upstairs in a loft--where I saw a couple dancing.

Okay to hang out for a few drinks, I guess..try it once.
author: C Q.

description:
How come for every single bar I've been going to, it always gets so packed you couldn't squeeze a fart if you tried to?!

Albeit, this place actually feels kinda homie.  It's seated next to an expensive parking lot ($10), in a seedy neighborhood, but it still felt like home.  The lighting sets the ambiance, and there's actually seating!

I still can't escape the asian domination though.  Even here.  For someone who's asian, living in a city populated by asians, I guess I can't win every fight.  

Oh, and on my way out of the seedy alley this place calls home, I almost ran over a contingency of friendly homeless folk.
author: Alfred Y.

description:
Met up a few friends while were in SF for Outside Lands in Aug and I really like this place.  It's on this small street in the cut and away from the main streets of SF.  

We arrived there and there was a bit of a wait just because there was a band that went on before and they had to pack up.  Once we got in, I totally dug the space and how the bar is set up.  It was a bit packed when we got in, but it was too hard to find some space.  The music was pretty good on a Saturday night and everyone seemed to be having a good time.

One major complaint: the bartenders there are f'ing inept.  I dunno how many times they messed up on our friends' drink orders.  Especially this one chick who thinks she's an amazing bartender, when in fact, she's terrible at what she does.  She screwed up ringing up my drinks and said "you're sooo lucky, omg, you're soo lucky." Honestly, she was just an idiot and doesn't know how to push buttons on a register.

Other than the rookie bartenders there, this is a great bar to meet your friends and enjoy some good drinks (if the bartenders don't mess it up).
author: Danny S.

description: I'm so lucky to have this neighborhood bar literally in my neighborhood. Great vibe and decor. Come to John Colins!
author: Helen Y.

description:
This place was pretty fun.  It would be much better for say...cocktail hour though.  I went on a Friday night and was getting grabbed pretty much alllll night.  I did not have my date with me so, I guess I felt like a bit of a sitting duck but- man- it was a total meat market.  The music was cool- I started dancing in the middle of the four foot wide walkway- but started re-thinking once I got goosed and didn't know where it was coming from...man that place was PACKED.

Great bartender who bought me a drink...he was cute too (love you, random bartender that buys me drinks :)
author: Stacy L.

description:
I have mixed feelings about this place now. It's awesome for HH and early night drinks, but definitely not the place to go for weekend nights. Recently, the front door has become unbelievable. You are a BAR - I repeat, a BAR - not a club. You really don't need to be telling people that an even ratio of guys: girls is required, and then turn away loads of people. 

It's just an ok spot now. I really prefer DaDa down the street.
author: Adrienne C.

description:
I recently went here for the first time on a rainy Saturday night, and based on the other reviews of this place I wonder if the rain kept things mellow...my friends and I were able to order our drinks immediately upon sidling up to the bar, and we were also able to score a few seats there as well.

The crowd didn't really stand out in one way or another, the decor was cool, the music was good (the DJ was spinning hip-hop on this particular night), the bartender was on top of things and the (slightly overpriced) drinks went down quite well.

I'd check this place out again, but would hope for the emptier version I enjoyed as opposed to the one mentioned in several of the other reviews...
author: Art D.

description: Not much of a fan of this place. The location is good (right in downtown) and drinks are a good price but the music is way too loud for how they bill themselves and it gets way too crowded. Some places....you go there and you know you're going to have a good time. This is not one of those places.
author: Drew K.

description:
Welcome to the scene that is not the scene. As you may have gathered, i am not one  for the trendy. Granted,  i like nice thing but I prefer them to be unassuming. This leaves a bar like John  Colins somewhere in my middle ground. It is trendy but it is not trendy, hipster but not hipster and not entirely a scene. It is, however, pretty close.

The lay out  and deceor are fairly trendy and posh: small round black tables, black candle lit tables and little black and beige stools. Michael Jackson videos playing on the LCD project, wait, no now it's Friday; no now it's an 80s breakdance movie. The bar carries an atmosphere of chic for chics sake that I tend to find distasteful. In kind the clientelle is inches away from being your standard "collar up"
 Marina affair; the type of person that if you're not already in you have to prove yourself alright  brah? You'll find your mix of pricks and chill people for both gender, so it's a crap shoot on what you'll come across.

The staff, however, is amazing. The bouncer is perhaps the kindest and most patient man i have  met in some time, both to the patrons and the neighbors. The bartenders are fast and attentive to the point of seeking you out if you look like you're trying to get a drink. Even when the bar is crowded, which it more than likely will be.

John Colins teeters on the edge being a nice place to mingle and socialize or steer clear from because of the pretenious socialites. It is tough to get a good read on the first go, but by your second time there you'll be able to tell if it is for you or not.
author: Keith M.

description:
First time here was after work for hhr. That was crowded and full of the financial district crowd. The second time I came here it was midnight, the place was full but not packed, people were dancing, and I had an AWESOME time. The bartenders are so nice (and cute!). The bouncer was a sweetheart too! All in all a really pleasant time. The artwork was a really nice touch and really made the place feel welcoming.

Yeah, I think I will be back.
author: Annie T.

description:
new favorite bar
Pavel = best. bartender. ever.




It feels DAMN good to be back in SF!.... ;)
author: Mona N.

description:
I have never been one for a traditional 'happy hour' mostly becasue I think that every hour of the day should be happy hour.  It is not uncommon to see my slurring my words at 11am after starting with a 40 oz. at 8:30. No joke.

So, I look at happy hour as amature hour... I am a pro... don't get in my way.

John Colins is no different but my friend works there and get me free drinks for 6 hours.  I'm a pro... I can take this bar... it is like spring training.
author: Thadd L.

description:
I've been here a several times over the past few years and the vibe of this place has not changed. 

It remains a chill hangout spot attracting the casual, mature, good looking crowd, which is why we went here for my bday. I can't say I remember much about that night, but everyone told me they had fun and were glad we went to John Colins because we got to actually hang out with each other and not get stuck in some loud, crowded club. 

Love that there was no cover and no dress code. Had one of my favorite birthdays here and would recommend here for a good night with friends.
author: kim l.

description:
Nice little bar.  Gets crowded during happy hour (if you want a seat, send some peeps out early early to snag some).  Happy hour is $1 off drinks -- I'm not sure how much their drinks are, though, so I'm not sure if this is a good deal or not.

The crowd is mixed.  Dudes who wear backpacks, Balboa Cafe cougars, and chicks in pastel suits. 

I wouldn't make it a destination, but it's good if you work in the area.
author: S J.

description:
Only times I've been here, I've been or gotten super drunk. Like drunk, a guy walks up to my friend and tells her, I think your friend is sitting on the floor in the back of the bar, drunk.  Anyhow, really into this place: good music, cool crowd, located near a lot of other stuff.. don't know why I haven't been recently actually..

Sometimes on weekends there's a line though- which is annoying.. cause it's just a bar. But then every time I've been here I happen to be wearing some interesting (not necessarily slutfest) outfit and get let in right away. So... wear funny clothes :)
author: JJ W.

description:
Seems to be just the right mix of people for a fun night out.  There's only a few bars in the city where I feel like every neighborhood is well represented (Rye, Tunnel Top, Alembic), and bars that get a good mix of people from all across the city are always my favorites.

There was a DJ who was playing good music (at just the right volume).  Even better, there were enough people to keep the bar full without being crowded.

All-in-all, a great place to go with friends.  I'll be back for sure.
author: james s.

description: Even before walking in, I can say the bouncers were really nice. I hate places with prick bouncers. Bottle service was great. We were seated at the VIP section next to the door. At first, I thought it was going to be cold and uncomfortable, but as the place filled up, it was nice to be next to some fresh air. What I also liked about this section was the ottoman-like furniture-- my girls and I were able to leave our jackets and clutches in the inside compartment of the seats without  worrying about someone coming into our section and taking our things. The music was great, bartenders were attentive, and they even carried Blue Angel Vodka-- it's surprisingly hard to find a place that carries this stuff. I like that there's a separate room for the dance floor. Although people are dancing all over the place, there's less worrying about someone bumping into you while you grab your drink at the bar. Bathrooms are clean and easy to get to, and that's a major plus.
author: Nicolle B.

description:
Great little bar!  They maximized the small space well, it's tastefully decorated and the service was fantastic.  

We happened to be at a bar across the street but the John Collins doorman gave it a good sell so we checked this place out at about 8pm on a Friday night.  The major happy hour rush had just departed so we were lucky enough to grab a booth/seating area.  We had a bench against one wall and then enough small stools to seat our group of 6.  The music was no too loud or too soft, we were able to talk to each other without other people hearing us, which is perfect!  

My tips for John Collins:
1) Arrive before the crowd to grab a seat, this place fills up fast
2) Follow the rules while smoking on the street
3) If you are friendly to the staff, they will be good to you.  

I will be back to see you again John Collins, a great place for drinks and friends!
author: Ann M.

description:
It's a cool place to relax and chill with friends..the music is loud and really lively which is hecka cool...

the only thing though is the Gin and tonic was really weak...

otherwise than that, it's a cool place
author: John C.

description:
I kept thinking my friends were taking me to some place called Tom Colins...
I really liked this place!  Mixed crowd, music, friendly bartenders.
My best memory: A guy bought me a shot because I was doing the robot in the corner when I thought no one was looking!  Classic!
author: Robin H.

description: Great bartenders, nice place to go after work, but if you go later in the weekend it get's pretty nuts.
author: Aaron R.

description:
I think the drink is called the "Moscow Mule". Whatever it is, it's flippin' amazing. 

I never really review bars or clubs because they depend so much on crowds and nights, but I'll say -- this place will probably stay a "happy hour" young professional kinda joint for awhile (at least Monday-Friday between 5 and 7...)

Yum!
author: Han C.

description: Went there for a party and had a good time. Good drinks, incredibly friendly barstaff. It was crowded but not overwhelmingly so with a fun and hip mix of people. The giant bull-dog paintings were bonus too.
author: Nikki M.

description: You know, every time I've been here I've never felt comfortable. The people seem to be rather pretentious and the alcohol choices just didn't blow me away.
author: Lisa R.

description: Hmmmm. What looks to be a Baron Davis sighting, prettty decent music,  and decent drinks all makes for a good place to chill at. I didn't like how I was told to take off my SF Giants baseball cap at the door and again later on by a bartender when I saw three people wearing Giants baseball caps inside...
author: Gerard Y.

description: Happy hours are funner when you got goldfish crackers, and John Collins has goldfish crackers mixed with pretzels right at the bar. Nice.
author: Earl G.

description:
Checked this place out with a friend on a Thursday night. It was -packed-. Service was fairly slow. The tonic water was off. And the signature cocktail I ordered, which was listed as containing Bulleit, was made with Jack. I was not impressed.

Maybe on a slower evening this place would be worth checking out, but not when it's busy.
author: Todd N.

description:
I LOVE the space here!  Especially before dark when the light filters through the skylight onto the exposed brick walls.  

The bartenders are cool and they have some kind of cucumber concoction, which I love!  The minus here is that it gets unbearably crowded on Friday nights, but most other nights are perfect.
author: Kyla B.

description: Rolled up to the place and there was parking right in front, pretty convenient. Walked up to the entrance and bouncer and people outside were pretty chill. Gotta love a bar/lounge with no cover charge, @ least when I went. The music was pretty dope, I hope they play hip hop all the time. Getting drinks took a little bit of time because of the number of people, but in my mind that's the mark of a good lounge. It was efficient nonetheless. The dance floor wasn't huge, but it was definitely large enough to fit 25-30 ppl it seemed like. There were nice wood shelves surrounding the dance floor which made setting your drink down easy enough.
author: Michael C.

description:
Had a great time with friends during "Happy Hour" on a friday! The atmosphere was very lively, everyone seemed upbeat. 
I thought it was a great hangout spot to meet up with friends.
Service was good.
author: Leon C.

description:
I've been a fan of this place since they opened, although I haven't been there (until this sat.) in quite some time.  I really like the feel of this bar.  It seems small and cozy to me, which I'm sure is due, at least in part, to the exposed brick walls and wooden beams.

The vibe here is great.  On Saturday night it was a good mix of chill people.  People were hip, but not tragically so. The bartenders are always super nice. 

This place is a good spot to actually sit and have a conversation over drinks with your friends.
author: Matthew R.

description:
I remember I gave Baron Davis a nod (wuddup) here when he used to live across the street.  I would soooo live here if this place was for sale~!   Brick walls, hardwood, awesome art work that changes every few months. It's dope they have a projector playing Breaking the movie! Classy meets urban for sure.. DJ booth upstairs along with VIP area, don't worry this place is wide enough to cut the dance floor with seating all around. 

Cover: Free
Music: 90's Hip Hop, 90's R&B, Rock, Pop, Top 40
Drink prices: Fair
Crowd: Mixed the way I like it. =)  

My Default spot.
author: Abraham E.

description:
Everyone needs a reliable spot for those nights when nobody knows where to go for drinks. This is mine. John Colins is off-the-beaten path so its usually not too crowded. If it happens to be when you arrive, just give it a little while and you'll have space in no time. (Its like the ebb and flow of an ocean.) It can be, however, drearily empty on weekday nights after the happy hour crowd has left. But that probably means you should go home and be a responsible adult too. Or not.

Thankfully the crowd isn't freshly-21 or the "unemployed", "10-year college plan" and "in-between jobs" types. Instead, its a good mix of 20- to 30-somethings who appear to be established and professional. (Since most people discover this place through post-work happy hours.)

Finally, the most important features of any good bar -- drinks are cheap, music is good and there is no cover or dress code.

Overall, its the perfect combination for those nights when you want to hang out with friends and just need a location.
author: eileen b.

description:
Absolutely loved this place, the decor, the people and the drinks.
Can' t wait to go again...
author: P J.

description: Dropped in on a suggestion. Bartender was friendly, Drinks stiff and good. They were playing 80's music, vibe was fun. Would definitely return.
author: carol s.

description:
Hmm. Probably one of my favorite bars in the city. I always find the atmosphere and patrons to be super chill. Not a whole lot of pretense. 

Stiff drinks, good music (especially when Sneake-a-Pete and Chilipino DJ there) and a friendly crowd. It's also a good location to hail a cab after I've had one too many.

Also, I love the artwork - - the painting of the SF cityscape. One of these days, I'm going to buy that sucker.
author: lily l.

description:
I've had my bday gathering here for the past few years.
It has a great open feel, and if you get there early enough you can have a large group seated comfortably... with the exception of asses crammed in your face from the hoards of people huddled in the middle of the room.

Fancy flowers on most mixed drinks. 
fun artwork on the walls. 
Line for the bathroom isn't horrible. 
Getting a drink might take awhile though. The actual bar is fairly small and 3 people deep on the 'good' nights. 

Not my kind of crowd though.  Lots of stink eye thrown around for no reason.
author: Towanda S.

description:
Small place that goes from chill at 5 PM to over the top loud by 6 PM. We stopped there on  a Friday after work to take advantage of convenient location and cheap drinks. Just as we sat down and started enjoying ourselves, the DJ showed up and started laying down the tunes that were shaking the walls. It was not just loud, it was really LOUD, the kind of loud you would expect at 1 AM in a packed dance club when you have shout to be heard. 

The place gets a lot of things right (cool space, nice art on the walls, reasonable prices) but the noise level was so off, we had to leave without finishing our drinks. What's the point of coming to a happy hour with friends if you can't chat?
author: Gina M.

description: Late Wednesday night my friends and I were looking for a one more drink and we decided to give John Colins a try. Walking in there weren't too many people and we took our seats at the bar. I really liked the decor and later found out that the bartender actually made a couple of the paintings. I was drinking beer, so I can't really comment on the cocktails. The staff was super chill and didn't rush us out the door at the end of the night.
author: Christy Z.

description:
I went to John Colins for Happy Hour recently. This was my first time to John Colins and I would have to say I was overall happy with the experience.

If felt a good vibe with the bar and the people. Everyone from the patrons to the employees were super nice and polite. I was even more impressed with how fast I was able to get a drink.

The music is so so...maybe it is just not my taste.
author: Victor I.

description: They moved to a bigger venue much better to move around.  I enjoyed the music and atmosphere.  The people were casual and the service was good
author: Jennifer H.

description: Nice lounge. Slick, spacious, dim-litted. Add a DJ, and John Colins can definitely set the mood. However, their pricey $10 cocktails tasted terrible. No tlc was given to the poorly made, watered-down cocktails that I was served. Still a cool place to hang with friends, but I think I'll be sticking with a coke.
author: Peter T.

description:
This is one of my usual hangouts when I'm in the xyz, Harlot, 111Minna hood.

Pros:  

1. Awesome location

2. Super cool bartender.... not that bad looking, too... if you're into the wife-beater shirt wearing bad-boy look.  My colleagues are infatuated with him.

3. Good vibe.  good music.  

4. Drinks are reasonable & reasonably priced (compared to Redwood room).

5. They have my favy shot: Crown!  Every time I go there, they have never ran out.  

The not so-pro:
1. The lychee martini is somewhat bland.  If you have a sweet tooth like me, just order something else.
author: Sheryl S.

description:
The place has always been cool.  Bartenders here have always been great.  Just one thing:

Belvedere neat = straight up

Not on the rocks
No twist of lemon
Vodka should be ice cold if possible

Thank you for the generous pour though.
author: Bill P.

description: I really like this bar.  It's in the middle of an ally.  It's more of a bar and you don't really dance but the music is so good that I'm sorry, me and my girls dance. :)  The place is kinda small and does get pretty packed.  We used to come here a lot when Boom Dizzle (Baron Davis) lived right across the street.  Haven't gone back in a while but def a nice cool place to hang out with friends.
author: Kimberly C.

description: I've recently moved back to NYC but when I lived in SF and when I come back to visit, John Collins is my spot! Shout out to my fav bartenders, Tehaj and Jason. JC has a nice atmosphere and a cool crowd. The ages range from 20's to 40's but the vibe is so mellow it doesnt matter. Its great for happy hour after work...from 5p to 7p it kinda feels like its your own bar. Then from 7p to 10p its crowded and jumpin' jumpin'. They've recently added some new bartenders who arent so ummmmm, personable. Thats when I stopped going as much. But dont let that deter you. Grab a couple of good friends and get there around 6:30p and grab an area and seats and enjoy good drinks, good crowd and mellow music! Oh, and dont forget to grab you complimentary bowl of pretzels and gold fish! :-)
author: Monique M.

description: The famous John Colins, or J.C. as many of the locals call it, is a dancing and drinking bar. Although the place is lined with couches and tables, you cannot enjoy a conversation in there. It's definitely a texting environment more than a talking one. I am judging this place on one visit and I only stayed for one drink, so I'm just contributing a statistic. I do admit the bar itself is fully equipped and the bartenders and servers seem friendly. I heard that the old John Colins was more of a lounge where business professionals use to hang out in, while this new vibe is dominated of a college kid to mid-twenties crowd. Go here if you just want to drown yourself in snare drums and auto-tunes. Avoid this one if you want to tell your friend a secret.
author: William H.

description:
To be honest, I did not make it inside the bar, so this review is based entirely on their admission policy. I went last (Friday) night to join a couple friends celebrating their birthday. When I arrived, I texted my friends to let them know I might not have the patience to wait in the line outside, so one of them came out to wait with me. While we stood outside for 15-20 minutes, about 10 people back from the front, the line did not advance one bit. Over a dozen people left the bar but still no movement. However the bouncer repeatedly let groups of women in-- some of them just walked to the front, some were plucked out of line. As the bouncer pulled the three women in front of me, I told my friend this was too absurd and insulting, so I was leaving. The bouncer then told me that it was "pretty full in there." My friend assured me it was not, and there were fewer people in the bar than when I arrived.  But either way, if it's so full, why are you letting in all those women?

Based on the people I saw and the music I heard, I would guess this is a pretty mediocre-to-douchey establishment, but since I did not get inside, I won't make assumptions.

A number of other reviews here say this place has a high bro quotient, so perhaps their admission policy is meant to balance that out. I don't know. All I can say is, I would recommend John Colins to women who like bars that are full of other women and to men who don't mind a long, degrading wait in line.
author: Daniel S.

description: How did John Collins move into a bigger space and make it feel smaller than the old one, and without the warmth and character of the original.  Friday happy hour service was totally FUBAR.  I couldn't get within ten feet of the bar and there was only one cocktail waitress who was eternally in the weeds.  I'm not saying it's a bad spot, I'm just saying it's not such a good one any more, which is tragic, because it is a half block from my office.
author: Quinn S.

description:
I really like the atmosphere of this place: exposed brick, wooden beams, and episodes of Robot Chicken projected above the doorway.  The drinks are normally made right, and the staff is friendly and efficient.  Normally, you can expect to find a nice place to sit with your friends and have a conversation and a few drinks.  

If I can say anything bad about the place, it is only that it should be avoided when it is too crowded (which certainly happens from time to time), but I suppose that is true for any place.
author: Matthew H.

description:
Eh.

Pretty chill place...good music, decent crowd, I can't really remember what I drank here this night (because we went for a friend's birthday and our drinks were paid for, not because I am an alcoholic..on this night at least). If you don't like sitting, this is the place for you.

The two things I remember are:

1. We broke many of their glasses, and I tipped the ice bucket over at least three times. I was drunk. Sorry.

2. The line for the men's line was extremely long, because some guy was droppin a fatty deuce. At least, that's what I told all the guys in line (half were my friends, I'm not an asshole, really). I recall it was initially intended to be a funny prank, but once the bartender came out and knocked on the door, I knew there was no going back. In addition to his notifying the Phantom Pooper about the long line, I was screaming, "Dude, pinch it off! There's a line out to Bayview here!"

By the way, not one person jiggled the handle to see if the door was actually locked, including myself.

Anyway. It was funny at the time, but you know. I was drunk. Sorry.
author: Sachi T.

description: Down a very non-descript alley in the shadow of the Bay Bridge approach lives John Colins.  (What's with the one "l", Colins?  You too cool for two?)  The inviting space has low benches and tables lining the walls and leads back to a full bar and an upstairs room which I did not explore.  They had St. George's (GO ALAMEDA, GO!) seasonal Spiced Pear vodka (fantastic with soda) and after a few of those, I don't recall much else about the place.
author: Laura B.

description:
Its like your first crush. You will never quite get over him,  nor do you want to. Its like your favorite t-shirt. The one thats faded and raggidty looking , but you love it anyway. Its like the first spoonful of the best Mac N Cheese! John Colins is that kind of place. 

Good people. Good music. And I love the old school porn. Thats REALLY  why I keep coming back. The Bartenders are the nicest in the city. And not to mention easy on the eyes.
author: Cin H.

description:
This place is exactly what a working professionals bar should be; good friendly crowds; good looking people; great drinks; semi-hidden locale; et cetera.

There is always a good, friendly crowd there.  It does get packed at times, but there's an obvious reason for that; people want to be there.

And to K O City's comments about it being a "borderline sports bar," that's absolutely bogus.  I know the owners very closely, and the last thing they want John Colin's to be is anything remotely close to a sports bar.  I don't know where you're getting that.  You may have gotten their customized John Colin's t-shirts (which look like a knock off of a Jack Daniel's logo) confused with something else.

You would do well to find yourself at this bar.
author: Phillip B.

description: Well put together, nice video screen setup
author: Pat M.

description:
THIS REVIEW IS FOR THE OLD JOHN COLLINS.  THEY MOVED AND NOW I AM SADDENED 


5 STARS because this place is what kicked off a magical night for me and my friends.. We first got our drinks. Ok i watched the bartender and seriously whatever he made had alcohol to the TOP.. added a few things to the top and it didnt taste like alcohol at all.. uhh, i got loose and FAST... The music was good, hip hop, not radio but lounge type hip hop. felt like I was back in NY for a minute too.. Good crowd of young pro's...
author: Dee L.

description:
So when I fail to make plans/figure out what is going on where I usually end up going to John Colins. This bar is best described as winner, and you can't lose with a winner. The music is always on point as well as the foxy bartenders who have that whole bad boy appeal going on while they make unbelievably tasty concoctions! This is a great place to go for everyone, the crowd is always super diverse. 

If you are looking for a feel good place, go to John Colins.
author: Henriette P.

description:
I really like this SOMA artsy slightly divish bar on Fridays.  Does that make sense??  Lots of professionals come here after work.  So you'll see groups of people from different companies.  I like hanging out w/ them because you feel like you have this strong connection or bond just cuz you all work within the small area of the Financial District haha.  Lots of dudes though.  But got lots of drinks I guess.  Got pretty drunk.  Man that was fun.

There's an upstairs private room... tried going there but got kicked out cuz of a "birthday party".  Ummm i didn't believe them, but im not one to pick fights w/ unknowns.  I only like picking fights w/ my friends.
author: Labonee M.

description:
When we first walked in, we almost ran right back out due to the wall/sea/herd of people in there. It was Friday during Happy Hour so I expected it to be crowded but not THAT crowded. 

However, I'm really happy that we stayed because once we moved to the back, where it was less crowded, I had an awesome time. 

Beers were pretty cheap, and all the cocktails had pretty orchids. Of course while intoxicated every girl in there put it in their hair, making it look like a luau in SOMA. 

The bartenders were really friendly, especially the co-owner, John. Even though the bar was packed, he was really attentive, and hooked it up with beer. (The asian girl + french girl combo works well) He even opened up a little Pommery Pop for my friend and I to share with him once he found out that she was French and that I studied in France. Truly amazing service!

As Happy Hour turned into Happy HourS for us, we started analyzing their business strategy drunkenly, to the extent of estimating price per decorative orchid. 

Good times. We will def go back soon! =D
author: Jenn C.

description: I do love the new location - still a cool, hip sophistication to it! I still love the music they pump out of the upstairs room ... But I have to say, the crowd - on Saturday evenings - not my thing. Bummed! :0(  I believe Weeknights are the way to go for me ...
author: Nicole Rynee B.

description:
Love Collin, Love John, Love the goldfish and pretzels which accompany my adult beverages, Love art, Love the Scarface-style scenario upstairs... LOVE THIS PLACE!

Let's grab a drink there now!
author: Rada I.

description:
I went to this place with my friend as we alternated between Harlot and here. i felt like this place wasn't enough to pick my interest. We grabbed a quick drink here and chilled for a while. The crowd is mixed and more young professional types. It was relaxing and the people were friendly. Drinks were good and a good place to chill. 

I would rather go here to hang out during the day than at night. Like i said, I can get bored easily here and try to find something else to interest me.
author: T. T.

description:
Great place for Happy Hour. It's well lit with great beers on tap for a great price. 

It's also right around the corner from work. 

I loved it so much, I've Happy Houred 3 times in the last week! The bartenders are friendly and I'm especially intrigued by the specialty drinks they make. I also love the free snacks that come with. 

Get here before 5:15. This place gets packed by 5:30...
author: Alyson C.

description:
Oops...at some point in the night I told a bunch of my friends we were going to Phil Collins.  They still tease me about that.

I'd go back, but there are some MAJOR improvements that should be made on weekend nights.  Some things that detracted from an otherwise great night-

1. Have the people who run the place ever heard of HVAC?  I'm a few decades too young to feel like I'm having a hot flash at a bar.  The dance floor was especially reminiscent of a sauna, and let's not talk about the BO.  Minus half star.
2. Bathrooms.  Three single-person bathrooms for the whole place produces line cutting and grouchiness.  It seems to me it would help business to have more bathrooms, as people would have more time to buy drinks!  Minus half star.
3. The worst one of all: bouncers at closing time.  No trouble getting in, but when it's closing time they turn downright rude.  I totally understand being forceful about getting a bunch of people outside of your establishment when it's time to close shop.  But when those people are being perfectly civil on the sidewalk outside your establishment, you have no right to YELL at your patrons to "GO HOME".  I seriously doubt the sidewalk belongs to John Colins.  A shame, as it left a pretty good night on a sour note.  Minus one star.

Aside from that, definitely loved the music and drink selection.
author: Yushan K.

description:
This is THE place to be..........if you're from LA.  It tries to be a lot of things, but ends up being scattered and just doesn't get it right.

Is it a lounge?  Why the hell is the music so loud?  Sometimes the music is so loud I can't even feel my phone vibrate.  Yes.  Phone.  Vibrate.  No feel.  And, shouldn't lounges have more places to sit?

For such a small place, I took note that they have a pretty good selection of scotch.  But, for a hipster bar why are the velvet chairs/foot stools all over the freakin place like land mines?  Nothing says cool and sophisticated when Mary Kate trips over a velvet box and spills her mango tamarind-tini all over ashley's ear and neck.  3 more points if said foot stool slides across and stumps ashley's toes AND spills it on Tony the tool who bought Mary Kate the cucumber cooler.

I would have scored it lower if for not the fact that these LA chicks can look stunning even sans alcohol.  Why must God smite me so?
author: Don B.

description: If your looking for a place just to have a kick back spot after a hard days work. Try definitely try this place. Its chill during the week with happy hours and the party gets more crackin on the weekends.
author: Victor A.

description:
Chill spot
Lounge feel
Good drinks
Cheap drinks
Great music mix
Bartenders are nice
The bouncer is a nice guy
Looking for a chill place this is a spot to hit
Not too loud that you can't talk to your neighbor
                        Hi neighbor

Will chillax there again.
author: Po L.

description:
Crowd control please!

I come here because my friends' live in the SOMA and it's an easy walk.  Other than that - I find that it sucks when you're buzz and there is no where to dance.  Actually, there is absolutely no movement space!!!  And really if you can't dance - there's not much I want to do.  Talking is out of the question - who really has a  convo in a bar on a Friday/Saturday night??
author: Julie H.

description: The set up is pretty cool with a full bar, small lounge area with what seemed like a (very small) dance floor, and upstairs for private parties. Decent size and still gave you a bit of a dive bar feel to it. Would've given a 5 star if they got my drink right (got vodka soda instead of tonic).
author: Samantha C.

description: Oh, John Colins! The very thought puts a smile on my face. The bartenders are sweet (most of them), nice to look at (most of them) and know how to make a drink. I've been coming here for almost a year now and have yet to have a weak or bad drink. I like going with my girlfriends on super dry nights -- there aren't any Djs on those nights but their Pandora stations are always ON POINT! It will have a bitch breaking off the bar stool! If you go on a Thurs/Fri/Sat it's guaranteed to be packed. Like, your bangs will be sweaty as fuck and glued to your forehead. The crowd is always whatever, I never see anyone attractive there EXCEPT for the fine ass drummer they have for their Samba nights! I get a really good work out on those nights. Thursday's they usually have some event like Femme Fatale or usually a live show of local music artists. It all just really depends on the day and event but I always have a good time when I go. There is no real dress code....I've seen hippies in there and caked-on makeup, club hoes. Pay them no mind, just take a few shots and pop yo pussy on the dancefloor babygirl. You'll be in bliss.
author: Lydia L.

description:
Cool crowd and a cool bar.

I really love the vibe and feel of this bar.  The lighting, the decor, and the staff adds so much to this place.   It is a relatively small place, but there is enough room for it to be comfortable.  The staff great, and I can get my drinks pretty quickly.  They are also noticeably more upbeat and friendly than most comparable bars.  I love the decor in this place.  The murals on the walls, and the green-house like ceiling, adds to the great ambiance.  The lighting is very sleek and sexy.  I really appreciate places that set up atmospheres.  

The place can get a bit tight on really busy nights, but it is pretty easy to get a drink.  Also, no matter how crowded the place can get; the crowd is pretty cool here.  There's just a good mix of people in the place.  Besides that, there is no real rudeness if you accidentally bump into someone.  People realize that it is actually very crowded and these things happen; but apparently this fact eludes other people in crowded bars.   

Great SOMA hipster spot.
author: Satoru Y.

description: My first time here for a friend's bday last night and I had a good time! Good drinks, good service, good crowd, n pretty good music. A lot of techno I think but my friend requested hip hop w/no problems so it really wasn't too bad.
author: Mercy D.

description:
Sometimes it's hard for me to articulate why I like one bar, and don't like another. In this particular bar, I feel like people go to be seen. It is mobbed with some pushy dudes. Maybe it's like this: there are bars that are clearly filled with single people that want to get laid. Everyone is looking around to see who is looking at them. This is accompanied by annoyingly loud music. Then there are bars where no one cares who is watching. They want to get drunk with friends and be able to talk. Getting laid is a bonus, not a goal. I obviously prefer the latter. This bar looks nice on the inside, but it is not conducive to sitting around chatting with friends. There are limited places to chill, so everyone mobs the bar and you stand shoulder to shoulder fighting your way in for a drink. You can't fault a bar for the crowd that gathers there, so here are a few pros and cons:
- Waitstaff walks around replenishing a little bowl of goldfish and pretzels. Nice touch.
- There is a cocktail waitress, which is awesome, but we could have used two or three more.
- No drink menus at the bar, or that the waitress could provide. It was too crowded to go to the bar and view the selection, so I couldn't order anything unique or special to that establishment. I had a gin gimlet, and the glass was about half full. My friend's glass was all the way full, so I paid the same for half the martini. Little inconsistent. 
- They have a happy hour of $1 off everything, which is A-ok.
author: Merrilee T.

description:
Celebrated my birthday here 2 Saturdays ago.  At first I was a bit hesitant to pick this place since I have never been to this place nor their old location.  After my first happy hour that same week, I made the decision and I didn't regret it. 

I talked to John (owner) and gave me their business card, got in touch with his wife, Leyla, who was in charge of reservations/events. She was friendly and accommodating and got me a good deal with their bottle service ($500/2 Grey goose bottles) and the foyer right by the entrance.  That location was the best, close to the entrance/exit, dance floor, bar, and restrooms (only 3 to be exact). If you have AT&T, reception is spotty down to a dead zone if you're really way in the back but they were willing to give their passcode for their Wifi, which gave me other means of communication thru my IPhone (facebook, textfree, textnow etc) to contact my friends (yes there is an app for that). You have to be very specific to the bouncer about guests coming after a certain time (1030pm, i think), there's gonna be a long line outside, and they won't just let you in, not unless if you know them, or if it's your event. Good thing we were just right by the entrance so I could see if my friends were outside plus with wifi, communication was not really a problem (good luck trying to send/receive calls). Our pretty cocktail server was really good to us, her name was G (short for something but I forgot what it was). She really knows how to give their guests a good time. Music was cool. Overall, I liked the place and wouldn't mind celebrating here again!
author: Christian L.

description: Good music, strong drinks, and bartenders not knowing who came first. The only negative of the night, so be prepared to make ppl. know you came before them. My friend's pear martini was too strong. Music was good, but swayed too much on the reggae side. Chill, fun group that shows up.
author: Thomas L.

description: Cool place for drinks after work. DJ on the second level, good drinks and a fun afterwork crowd. The space is a bit tight and it was definitely packed but it was still a good time.
author: Debbie C.

description:
let's see...

nice atmosphere
ok drinks

but service?? 10 thumbs down!!!

i came for a drink tonight with my friend. I walked up to the counter where the bartender was making a drink right in front of me. He was making drinks so i didn't want to interrupt his flow. I just stood there waiting for him to acknowledge me. 
He finished his drink, didn't bother to look up and walked off. putzing around on the other side, determined to ignore me.

then another douche bag came along, made his drinks in front of me again, and AGAIN, walked off. After a gazilion minutes, he finally came around to get me a drink. with an attitude like i am an idiot for waiting at all. 

Then he walked off, buzy making some drinks. half way there he went off to check his phone, decided to charge it somewhere else. came back as my drink had already melted away in the mixer.

the other guy was standing in front of me making drinks again, and after a gulping gazillion minute finally decided to ask me if i had been help. 

Then the guy came back after finishing with his critical duty of attending to his phone with two shot glasses and turned out they had so much down time that they needed to do their own shots before they could make my drinks..

Second round of drinks, same experience. My friend actually laughed at me, he said he should learn to show some flesh.  But they don't deserve it.

I AM NOT A SUCKER FOR CORPORATE STYLE INSINCERE SERVICE ATTITUDE, WE ARE TALKING ABOUT BASIC HUMAN DECENCY TO GREET SOMEONE, ACKNOWLEDGE THEIR PRESENCE. THAT'S ALL!! it's just what people do in a civil country, how hard is that???

why did I even tip them at all? I can be such an idiot!
two stars for two As&h&les!!
author: Xiu L.

description: I really didn't like this place when I first walked in.  It was after work and I was looking forward to a chill bar where we could just sit down and grab a couple of drinks.  Well, the bar was way too crowded.  My friends and I could barely find a place to stand.  But after we got our drinks, a table freed up and I started to have fun.  John Collins has a nice chill vibe to it.  It gets a little loud with all the people in there, but I didn't mind that at all.  The crowd starts to die down as the evening progresses, but this is a good place to go to grab a drink after work and then head off to dinner.
author: Elena N.

description: Great viewing area for the game with big projector screen...but happy hour isn't that great of a deal.  $2 off any drink is normally good but my vodka soda was $7, meaning $9 normally.  Pretty expensive, even for happy hour.
author: C. G.

description: Love it! Perfect for thirsty Thursday's and well, just Friday's innit.
author: Kym P.

description:
This bar is right behind my work. I have come here for welcomes, farewells, meeting with sales reps and god knows what else.

I have come here with workmates. I have come here with international visitors. But most importantly... John Collins is where we had our first date, BF and I. 

My bar selection must have been impressive since things are going well :p
author: Joyce L.

description:
John Colins is one of my favorite bars in the crowded SOMA area around 2nd and Mission. Though there are many places to have a drink around here, such as DaDa, John Colins manages to keep me coming back with their laid back vibe, good music, happy hour, and tasty cocktails.

The fully stocked bar stretches across the back and includes an excellent assortment of rums and tequila. They have their own drink menu with specialty cocktails that follow a tropical theme, hence the wide selection of rum and tequila. Most of the house cocktails run $8-9 and are $1-2 off during Happy Hour.

Mondays are happy hour all day long! It's the perfect spot to spend a Monday evening run by going to another bar for happy hour until 7, then hopping on over to John Colins to continue drinking on the cheap with good company and music. Full review on my blog, see profile.
author: Gene M.

description:
This small bar, nestled in between a taqueria and a parking lot, hosted my first DYL, which turned out to be pretty cool.
The atmosphere is dark, with seating areas along the sides, and a bar towards the end. Music was pretty much chill out, but not tso much to fall asleep to. There's a small upstairs VIP room, that seems to be a little too small, and detached from the rest of the bar, since the DJ booth is in it and right next to the window/opening that looks into the bar. The skylight adds a fine touch during day drinking.
Service was pretty decent considering the amount of people. I found a strategic spot to get a drink in relative quickness (which i am not revealing, of course).
I'll take 1 star off, because the restrooms are 1 person at a time, so plan ahead, and when you feel the slightest biological need, go and make the line.
author: Esteban P.

description:
As I Ieft this bar I was immediately confronted by domestic violence.
-1 star.
I then got sucker punched and upon returning to the bar/restaurant to report the issue I was informed that I would be the person to be informed on!.
-5 stars
Apparently they will do  anything to keep from having bad publicity associated with them.

lesson learned? if you want to beat your wife/girlfriend, do it in front of John Colins. 
John Colins is "beat your girlfriend" friendly.
author: Henry C.

description: Visited the new john collins for the first time. i used to go to the old location which was smaller but  awesome. this place is bigger and better, although i do miss the upstairs brick room where the dj booth - private, secluded, (not just for vips), over looking the main floor. Met the bartenders, asked to take their picture so i can post it on here, but it got deleted from my phone. soooooo, luckily the guys there are good sports and would probably do another photo opp, so thats  a plus. They have an upstairs booth that's about to open to the public, so we'll see how that goes. i hope its not just for vips. the new decor is nice. It still has the brick wall. i dig that. as for the partons, i couldn't get a feel for the type of crowd yet...looks diverse and friendly. will have to go a few more times =)
author: Shayenne G.

description:
Never knew SF nightlife existed until I came here on a random Wednesday. Although it was pretty happening here, the place is very small with a few sitting areas in the front and the bar towards the back. It has a tropical island beach theme going along with the reggae music. Not sure about the other drinks but I took a sip of a friend's Hurricane and straight up tasted like lighter fluid.

This place isn't my cup of joe but its a chill spot for people with no daytime obligations in their life to drink on a Wednesday.
author: Ed L.

description: Was in this bar for the first time at the weekend with my irish friends, wr all loved it!! Great music and great atmosphere. Will definetly be back!!!!
author: Melissa M.

description: So when I feel like sticking in my neighborhood...this is one of the few bars I think of. I like vodka and they happened to have a decent special this past Friday nightt on Stoli berry vodka or some flavor they have. Definitely did not dent my wallet that night.
author: Helen V.

description:
Good bar, lots of bar tenders on a very busy night meant that drink orders were quickly fulfilled and getting a drink was relatively easy.  The bar tenders and the door guy were nice and noticeably courteous, I appreciate that about a place.
The place was packed and it is narrow, sardines come to mind...Filled with sweaty drunk people elbowing each other and yelling to be heard.  
If you have to go to a bar, this is a good one.
author: Nilu r.

description:
Saturday Night

Cover- Free for guys and girls

Parking- good luck finding a spot on the street. Ended up parking at a garage on 3rd Street which is $7 flat rate in the evenings (not too bad I guess). You just got to get your car out by 2:30 AM I believe. 

Music/ Dance Floor- Super small, but it doesn't seem like many people dance here anyway so it wasn't too bad. Music was good in the beginning playing top 40's and old school hip hop. However, by the middle of the night- the music was just weird. It was like a mix of electronica/house/alternative- I don't even know how to describe it. The DJ was feelin it though, everyone just looked confused haha. 

Drinks- just like any other bar in SF. I wasn't here during happy hour, so can't vouch much for it like the other yelpers. However bartenders were nice though. They messed up on my friends order, so gave us extra shots.

Line/Wait- For some reasons there were alot of guys that nights, so they ended up not letting any more guys in unless it was an equal girl to guy ratio. Haha it felt like the girl:guy ratio rule in Vegas, which I thought was kind of funny for such a small SF joint. Our group lucked out because we had an equal ratio. The group of guys in front of us had to bounce. 

Overall- I think this place is more for an older crowd or those who just likes to drink and chill. Then again, it seemed hard to strike a convo here since it's pretty loud. This place is more for a chill night in my opinion (nothing too crazy). Probably not the best place to hit up in SF if you're down for dancing and good music. Free cover though.
author: Cindy L.

description: Nice enough bar, and they let me bring in my Curry Up Now food in. But I was unimpressed with the beer taps, save for Trumer Pils. Would've been nice to have some Fat Tire, Boont, or the local stars Anchor and Prohibition.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
Great little side-street bar!  I love the exposed brick walls and high ceilings.  The bar staff is great...the owners, John & Colin, pour good drinks back behind the bar but they don't hold a candle to Chelsea, who pours a stiff drink and makes it look good!  It got a little too packed on a Friday night with a stuffy Fin. Dist. crowd, but there are some other great bars in the area to escape to if need be.  Love the skylights but it would be uber cool if they used it in some artsy way.  All in all, a SOMA hidden gem!

Drink of choice:  Dark & Stormy... a rum & ginger beer concoction that gets the taste buds going and the imagination lingering on fun things to do when the weather is just that... : )
author: Tara G.

description:
Updated 3/29/07:

Well I had to raise my rating of this place to 4 stars because they seem to have improved. It's actually a good after work bar in SoMa now. They have a happy hour that is $3 well drinks and $2 beers. I LOVE happy hour so this makes me quite HAPPY. The crowd and the music seem to have improved also.

-----------------------------------------------------------------
STRONG DRINKS, BLAH PEOPLE, BAD MUSIC

This is a relatively new bar and much like Zebulon, I have to say PASS.

It's a really cute bar with lots of potential and the bartenders served strong drinks but the DJ was killing me. I've been here twice and both times, the music sucked.

The bar is a little more packed right after work but later on, it seemed dead. I have a feeling that everyone is over at 111 Minna instead...

DITCH THE DJ!
author: Cindy P.

description: John Colins is always a good first or last stop on a fun-filled night.  John and Colin are some of the nicest guys you'll ever meet.  Though the bar can get packed, the bartenders are super attentive and never make you wait too long.  The parking lot next door is a huge plus too.  The music is great and the movies projected on the wall are a nice touch.  Shout out to Pavel for the boot shots!  But never give me that chili tequila ever again!  I'm still recovering...
author: Jessica H.

description:
John Collins is a good place to go after work, provided you get there reasonably early so as to beat the crowds. But be warned, it gets _incredibly_ crowded. When I worked in SF this was a common after work bar for my office (I worked in the old Chevron building on Market, so this was basically in our back yard).

Of note is that the Tamale Guy shows up here most nights. If you don't know what I'm talking about, you obviously don't spend enough time in enough San Francisco bars.
author: Josh O.

description:
We came here b/c Supperclub didn't get my friends' names on the guest list and i didn't particularly feel it was fair for my friends to pay full cover when the site didn't give explicit instructions on what getting on the list entailed... at any rate, we walked from where the supper club and decided on this place based on the yelp reviews and I was not disappointed.  

(THANK YOU yelpers b/c without you i would have never found this place!)

got in around 11 Friday night, not too crowded but not empty, it looked like some folks were already having a good time.  

Only minus one star b/c I practically had to shove my ccard down the bartender's shirt!  I probably could have walked away and he wouldn't have even noticed - and it wasn't even full to capacity!  Makes me wonder what it's like to try to get a drink on a Sat. night.  

The deco was chill with brick walls and dark wood bar.  Along the back was was a small bar area to put your drinks -- they had hooks on the underside of the bar thing - LOVE it, hung my purse and jacket there and didn't worry about them getting shoved on to the floor.  

Eventually got a couch - very cozy, my friends and i were able to catch up and hold a decent conversation - the music not too loud, but loud enough to have to make you lean in.  They were playing old school Michael Jackson vids & soul train hip hop edition or something on the bigscreen - very entertaining, must have been about 12 years since i've watched "Thriller"! 

The restroom was decent, at least at the time i went.  Like i said, everything was dandy cept for that first bartender who didn't want to take my money... i guess i coulda walked away, but i'm honest like that and believe in karma.  

Since I walked, dunno how the parking situation is.. but it's SOMA, so parking could be an issue at some point.
author: Ella B.

description:
I have gone to this bar twice. Both times had totally different experiences. The first time, packed with people and moving through the place involved touching a person with each step. The second time, it was pretty bare. The upstairs area is where the DJ booth is located complete with a few couches. 

The drinks are okay, but I hear the mojitos need some work. 

There is some street parking, but there is also a reasonably priced parking lots. 

This is more a hangout place to just chill. Not terribly exciting.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
Went here for my friends birthday party, not by choice, but the only thing near Harlot (at full capacity?? i think that's BS) that seemed ok to go to. Not a bad choice. This place was clean, had great music playing, and it was a very mixed crowd. 

Even though there were idiots roaming around, trying to sneak up on pictures, chodes trying to pick up girls with pick up lines from the pick up artist (VH1) how lame.

PLUS ONE FOR THE BOUNCER OUTSIDE JOHN COLINS. He an awesome dude... and plus couple other stars for the bartenders! HOOKING IT UP WITH DRINKS!

- one star for the fat girls dancing on the bar top... uhhhh get the fuck down.. you look nasty
author: Brian P.

description:
This place definitely needs no other reviews, but I want to add it to my happy hour list.
I think someone was having their work Christmas party while we were here, at least I hope that was the excuse for all of the people wearing Santa hats.  The atmosphere is nice, though the space heater got a bit hot.  It's pretty crowded, and takes awhile to get a drink, and there's not a huge pay off of eye candy, but overall a great happy hour spot as far as value goes.  
Beers are $2, wells $3, all other drinks $1 off until 8.
author: Sarah M.

description:
This is a good place to start off a night, or to chit-chat after work. They pour freely, the place has a nice vibe, and it's pretty fun. The people here are friendly.

The only thing is, my mate and I often come here - probably 2-3 times a week - and we never see anyone else who regularly comes here. Isn't that odd?
author: Andrew I.

description:
I had my 30th B-Day party here and it was awesome. I always loved going over here for H/H and to chill. The fire tequila is of course, something you need to try.

I was able to have the upstairs area for my party with bottle service which was great. The staff is great and helpful as well. I'm going to miss this place when they start doing the bus terminal extension.
author: Brian L.

description:
John Collins ought to be the kind of place that I like -- exposed brick, drawn curtains, cozy space. Alas, it just doesn't quite work for me.
